Entry.1:
Sailed from Sydney at noon on Sat Aug 19th. Tis a day I am not likely to forget in a hurry, but it was somewhat marred by the fact that there was not a soul on the wharf whom I knew except a few chaps from camp. The reasonof this was that I was an emergency man to the reinforcerment &was uncertain until 2 hours before the boat sailed as to whether I would be going or not. I did not like saying good bye to all my friends &then perhaps not sailing. Even if I had wished I could not possibly have said good bye to a lot of people as I only joined the reinforcement the day before they went down to the boat &then I was put on baggage guard at the boat the night before sailing &only gota few hours leave from 8pm to midnight. It took us the best part of Friday afternoon to put out all the hammocks



& mess things etc &after tea we drew lots to see who would go ashore, ½ to go until 8pm &the remainder to go when they had returned: I drew the 2nd lot &had to wait until 8pm though some of the first half did not come back untilnext morning. Not for one moment did I doubt but that I would sail on the next day &sure enough when the troops marched on board at 10am on the
Entry.2: there was one man missing in our reinforcement the
Entry.4: Regt. He was a Russian &had been taken by the police on a charge of assaulting a woman, & so I got his place to my great delight as it would have broken my heart I think to have had to stay behind having got so near to sailing. There were quite a lot of troops who came on board at Sydneyincluding a reinforcement of the Camel Corps, a reinforcement of NZMR (119). 2 reinforcements of Queenslanders
Entry.5:
&11th L.H.) &a few engineers &WirelessSquadronmen. There was a huge crowd on the wharf &an hour before the ship left there were hundreds of streamers out from ship to shore. Perhaps if I had any friends there I might have felt the departure more keenly thanI did which was keenly enough but at the same time I did not like the thought of sailing with even a soul I knew to wish me Godspeed &without saying good bye to anyone. At last 12 oclock came & as the ship slowly drew away from the wharf under the influence of a couple of powerful tugsthe streamers began to break slowly at first but quicker &quicker as we got further out until there were only a few long ones left &when these finally snapped there was great cheering both from the wharf &from the boat. Once out from the wharf we swung round facing



the Heads &gradually got weigh on. The wharf and its cheering crowd with waving hankerchiefs, got smaller &smaller as we drew away until we finally lost sight of the wharf round a bend. There were many sad hearts that day, although there was not a tear to be seen. It made one think of what we were leaving &appreciate as we never had done before perhaps the good old place we were leaving. Of the men on the boat that day there were a great number who were not to see Sydney again &before many months were passed we were scattered all over Egypt, some having already found graves in the desert. We crossed the heads at about 2pm &when outside made a big swing southwards for Melbourne. We all stayed on deck to see the last of Sydney &when the Lighthouse on Southhead had faded away in the distance we went down below to



examine our quarters. Perhaps it is time I gave some idea of the ship was to be our home for the next five weeks &on which we had a really good time. The RMS "Mooltan" for that was her name was a P&Omail boat of 10,500 tons displacement. She had none of the brightly painted upper works that characterized these boats in pre war days, but from the top of her masts tothe waterline everything was of a dull grey colour like a warship is painted. Many &many a time I had seen this ship lyingat Circular Quay when I was at St. Josephs butlittle did I think in those days that I was to leave australia in her to go to the greatest war that has ever been in the history of the world.To most of us who had never previously been on a big ship she seemed like a huge floating

mansion. I had once been to Melbourne (8 year before) in the "Wyandra" an inter state coaster of 4,500 tones but of her I have only a faint recollection. We carried 1st &2nd class passengers while the
Entry.6:
class part was reserved for troops. This had been converted into a troop deck extending from the fo'castle head to amidships, below the first saloon. A lot of the chaps had great difficulty in finding their way about down below butI did not have much trouble as I had been all over the ship prior to leaving Sydney. We had hammocks to sleep in with two blankets per man. In the day time these were rolled up &placed in receptacles for them in the corner of the mess deck. We drew our hammocks at 6 pm each night &put them away at 6 am each morning. Overhead on the roof were racks in which was a life belt

for everyman &also hooks on which to suspend our hammocks at night. On the floor were tables withforms, all fastened securely down, each table holding 14 men, 7 on either side. Underneath the table &running throughout its entire length was a broad wooden plank which was used as a receptacle for our plates &crockery etc. Each table was supplied with a bucket for drawing tea, while there were two bigdishes for meat &vegetables (tin)&one for pudding. In addition there were 2 enamel plates per man &a knife, fork &spoon each. To get upon deck we had a ladder up the hatchwayonto the "well" deck between the focastle head &the bridge. This method of egress could only be used in calm weather, as in rough weather the seas used to come over the bow &down the hatch wayonto our

deck. The well deck was considerably lower than the focastle & centre of the ship & as it was bounded on the other sides by the sides of the ship it thus gets its name, also because the hold goes down through the centre of it. Amid ships we had the use the hurricane decks extending from the well deck to the aft hatch & 2nd class quarters a distance of about 75 yards nearly on both sides of the ship. To get onto this deck one had to go up a commaion way to the boat deck
Entry.7:
class passengers only allowed here) along it for 7 or 8 yards & then down a flight of steps onto the hurricane deck. Later on we had a guard at top of the steps to prevent any loitering while going from the hurricane to the well deck & vice versa. The Mooltan had already had one escape from a Submarine in the Meditteranean

but owing to her superior speed was able to escape after a long chase in which she maintained a speed of 20 knots for some time. It was afterwards found that this had some what strained her engines & whenever afterwards she got up to 16 or 17 knots she used to vibrate a gread deal & sometimes you could hardly stand on the focastle head for the vibration. She was Sunk the following
Entry.8:
by a mine off Gibraltar. I was very sorry indeed when I heard of her going down as I had had a really good time on her for 5 weeks. The food on board was good but we did not fully appreciate it at the time & used to grumble some what. Many & many a time afterwards out on the desert I would have thought the same food luxurious. Still we never seem to know when we are well off & only appreciate

a good thing when we get something worse. Breakfast usually consisted of porridge, & bacon or steak. Had Pudding every day usually a plum duff one day & rice with fruit or figs the next. The duffs were fearfully heavy & were a good test of ones digestive powers. In addition we had plenty of butter jam & cheese & for dinner had either mutton, beef or stew & vegetables, &
wel
never did we have the same dish continuously as in the
army
camps where it is practically
stue
stew, stew every day until one got to hate the sight of it. We had a canteen down below run by the ships management at which one could get coffee, lime juice, biscuits cakes sweets, & tobacco & cigarettes etc at very moderate prices. The Cigarettes & Tobacco were so much cheaper than on land as they were duty free.

We had a YMCA representative on board who did practically nothing to promote concerts & sports etc which he was there to do, but spent most of his time with the
Entry.9:
Class passengers & among the nurses we picked up on the way round Australia.

Had a very calm trip round to Melbourne & no one was sick. Steamed through the Rip at about 6 am on
Entry.10:
& as we sailed up the Bay it began to drizzle with rain which was accompanied by a cold wind. Tied up to the wharf ar Port Melbourne at 9 am & immediately went ashore on leave until midnight. WSent to all the Public buildings not omitting the law Courts where we heard several cases going on. At night went to the theatre to see "The Girl in the Train". Melbourne gives one the impression of room & space as



the streets are much wider than those of Sydney & are laid out on a better principle - the Block System.Were not allowed ashore next day for some reason unknown. Towards sailing time a bitterly cold wind sprang up accompanied by rain which however did not prevent quite a large crowd assembling to see the boat off. At Melbourne we took on board some Wireless, Engineers & 50 nurses bound for Mesopotamia. Cleared the Rip just after dark & it was rather interesting to watch the searchlight from Queenscliff sweeping the sea sometimes lighting up the ship & sometimes on to the Pilot boat which accompanied us out to sea for some miles.

Had an uneventful trip to Adelaide except for some cases of seasickness when we ran into a slight swell. Arrived at Adelaide on morning

of 24th & berthed at the outer Harbour. We again got leave to go ashore, but by the time our special train reached the city it was midday. Tis just an hours journey to the city, through sandy waste land most of the way. Was rather taken up with Adelaide & prefer it to either Sydney or Melbourne as a city though it is very hot in summer I should say. The city seems so nice & clean, with a good tram service & wide sreet. The peculiarity of Adelaide is that all the buildings are down one long street, rather a novel idea I thought as in Sydney & Melbourne they are intersperced all through the city. Went to visit my uncle who ismanager of the Commercial Bank. Was very sorry that our time was so limited as we had only a few hours which would not allow of one going out

to the hills or any of the Environs of the city. Had to be back on the ship by 5 pm but did not sail until about 9 pm. It took us 4 days to go round to Fremantle with rough seas & head winds all the way. Quite a lot of the chaps were sick but I was not so affected. Once we passed Cape Leewin the weather moderated & the remainder of the journey to Fremantle was through comparatively calm water. The town lies about half a mile inside the Breakwater at the entrance to the Swan River. A mile or so out from the Breakwater is Rottnest Island, which is used both as a pleasure resort & as an internment camp for German prisoners of war. As we only got in just before sundown & were to leave again at midnight we only had a few hours leave ashore. Would liked to have gone up the river to Perth but time would not permit.

Quite a number of chaps got hoplessly drunk to celebrate the last port of call in Australia which a lot of us were destined never to see again.

Fremantle seemed a very uninteresting place indeed. We sailed at midnight of 28th & next morning were well out of sight of land, & for the next 9 days did not see a boat of any description ot even any land till we reached Colombo.

The weather was very hot going across the Indian Ocean, which was very calm all the way across. We slept up on deck at night after leaving Fremantle as it was almost unbearable at night down below. Our dress from now on was dungarees converted into shorts. shoes & singlets. For duty we did half an hours physical "jerks" every day & guard on the gangway about

once every 3 or 4 days. We used to be awakened every morning about 5 am by the hasears crying "washee deckJohny"& if we did not move it wouldresult in a wetting. For amusement we used to have Boxing Contests during the afternoon & concerts at night sometimes.

About 2 days out from Fremantle a gloom was cast over the whole ship by the death of a young Westralian who had only come on board at Fremantle. His death was caused by Haemohage of the Brain as the result of over excertion in a boxing contest. He died within an hour of the contest. We buried him at sea next morning about breakfast time. The ship was stopped & lay rolling quietly on the swell while we stood at attention round the messtables as the body was lowered over the side.

The young chap in question was very well liked & put up a splendid fight against a man much heavier than himself. We used the well deck as a ring & had tarpaulins spread overhead to keep off the sun's rays.

Twas about this time that I learned the rudiments of photography. One of my mates used to do a good deal & taught me how to develop etc. For a dark room we used a bathroom with the ventilators blocked up & all cracks etc covered to exclude light & in addition we put a red cape over the electric light. We would be shut in for about an hour at a time & at the expiration of that time would be absolutely dropping with persperation owing to the stuffiness of the room.

Flying fish were very plentiful going across the

Indian ocean. Arrived Colombo at sundown on 7th & left on night of
Entry.11:
Went ashore each day at 11 am for a route march along the seafront & then to the barracks where we were dismissed at 1 pm. We were then at liberty to roam around the town until 4 pm when we went back to barracks & thence to the ship.

Had several rickshaw rides. They charge 1/- per hour which is not too much considering that in that time they can cover quite a lot of ground at a fair trot. The natives drawing them are very wiry & seem tireless.

Silk goods were very cheap here being obtainable at about
Entry.12:
the price one would pay in Australia. When buying anything you have to beat them do in price as their first price is about 3 times the real value of the article. As we did not like haggling over prices I think we paid a lot

more for things than they were worth.

The Cingalese are absolute pests & from childhood are taught to beg. Their favourite cry is "me no father no mother no sister no brother no nothing give it one penny".

The Barracks are fine, airy, & spacious buildings but almost empty when we were there. The Gardens on the outskirts of the town are very nice. The vegetation is all tropical & grows very dense.

Horses are exceedingly scarce being conspicuous by their absence. Practically all vehicles are drawn by a small species of humped oxen, which are exceedingly strong. The native carts are covered over with wickerwork & are usually drawn by either one or 2 oxen.

In the centre of the main sq is a tall square shaped tower used as a town clock & as a lighthouse. The roads in & around Colombo

are excellent & are easily kept in repair on account of there being no heavy traffic on them. The residences of the Europeans are about a mile or so outside the town & stand back off the road amidst dense vegetation.

There are no verandahs around the houses or shops but some few of the latter have awnings put out over the footpath.

On Saturday our last day in port a mate and myself went around the harbour in a boat visiting several of the ships in harbour, all anchored out of course. Had a good look over a French packet boat the M.M. Cordilline bound for Cochin China. She carries a 75 mm as a stern chaser for submarines. Her passengers were a motely crowd comprising Indians, Chinese, French & some French soldiers on their way to Singapore.

She was an exceedingly dirty ship & not to be compared to our steamer.

Next we went to the Troopship A8, the Argyleshire bound for Australia. The next was a big dirty looking transport with a load of 600 mules on board from China to Italy & a Chinese crew. Near her was a small oil-steamer vey appropriately named the Castor.

The port seemed to be really too small for the amount of shipping that goes through there. The Harbour would be practically enclosed by a breakwater but for two breaks in it called the North & South entrances respectively. Tis usual to go in the Northern entrance & out through the Southern one.

On account of there being no wharves all the coal etc is taken to & fro by lighters. It took us a night & half the following day to coal, during which time we took on

board about 500 tons of coal.

At Colombo we lost the Nurses & Wireless who were bound for Mesopotamia.

I had a swim around the ship one morning in company with some others but we were promptly ordered out on account of sharks which however go out to sea in the day time & come in to feed at night.

After leaving Colombo we struck out in a N.W. direction for Aden. Had head winds & choppy seas until we struck the Gulf of Aden about a days sail from Aden.

We did not keep on the main trade route but took an unusual course. It took us almost 7 days to reach Aden, which is a couple of days over the scheduled time. The reason of the delay was that the boat from Bombay which was to meet us at Aden broke down & so we reduced speed to 12 knots so as not to get



into Aden too early. Near Aden the water is remarkably clear & we could see fish etc quite clearly to a remarkable depth. Sharks are very plentiful in these waters & even before going in we saw about 20 of the hammer headed variety while the harbour simply swarms with them .

Had a route march ashore each day when it got cool. Aden, I think is the last place God made & he forgot to finish it.

The town or what little there is there lays at the foot of some rough, barren hills which comes down to the waters edge almost. There are a couple of hotels, a few other buildings, the rest being barracks & hospitals.

On Saturday afternoon a ship came in with a cargo of Chinese labourers for France, where they were to do agricultural work on account of the shortage

of such labour existing there.

Left Aden about midnight & next morning on waking up found ourselves inside the Red Sea. Had fair breeze all the way up the Red Sea so that we did not get it as hot as is usually the case when going through this sea.Saw land on the first day but not so for the ensuing 2 days.

The Red Sea teems with fish, probably because it has never been fished to any extent & again on account of there being no market near at hand.

Due to arrive at Suez on evening of
Entry.13:
Got into Suez at tea time & disembarked at 6 pm. Got a good send off when we left the ship, from the passengers & crew who assembled at the rail to bid us good bye.

As we neared the land & the ship, now a blaze of light - receeded, we felt very sorry indeed at leaving.

Such a good home, for such she had been for almost 5 weeks.

Entrained in special trains for an unknown destination for which we left at 8 pm. At midnight we detrained at a place called Moascar (Arabic for camp) about a mile out of Ismailia. Marched¾ of a mile through heavy sand to the Isolation Camp, because we had had several cases of mumps on board.

About a mile away is the Canal running through L Timsah which was a mile across & in which we used to swim.

Have been doing drill while in Isolation Camp, including one week of mounted work. Were out in a sand storm one day & for about half an hour we could not see more than about 10 yards & got covered all over with dirt & sand, in our eyes, ears, etc.

The railway runs just past our camp & on

the other side of the line is a big Tommy camp containing anything up to 20,000 men.

Had 3 inoculations in the first week. Tis pretty monotonous in Isolation, as we have no means of getting out for a swim or of going in to Ismailia. Nevertheless some of us did go out a few times down to the main detail camp & down swimming at night even.

Won 100 yds Chmps of isolation camp today out of 16 starters. It was worth only about 10/- to me.

Voting for the Referendum took place on
Entry.15:
but I did not have a vote.

A riding school for young Tommy officers used to practise near our camp. They were awfully amusingas they all rode in Tod Sloan fashion (knees up) & none of them knew anything about riding. Their mounts (mules) used to take them all over the place & one evening in particular a young

officer of about 18 years of age was in great distress. His mule simply took him where it liked & eventually he had to get off & lead it back to the main lot.
Entry.16:
went out of Isolation today down into the main Details Camp. This is the main base camp for the L. Horse in Egypt.

The stables are made of light wood with rush work over the top. Each building is about 50 yds long & would hold as many horses or 75 perhaps. These stables were in 2 rows about 30 yards apart & ran the whole length of the camp in front of the tents, a distance of at least¾ of a mile. There were never many horses in the stables however.

Used to go swimming nearly every day in the Lake & I used to enjoy it immensely. On the way to the Lake we used to cross a fresh water canal about 25 yds wide that runs from P Said right to

Cairo almost through Ismailia & gets its name from that place. There was quite a lot of traffic on it - the old sailing boats with the big sails.

I was to learn a lot more about Egypt in the future & the part these canals took in it. Have been in Ismailia a few times but do not think much of it. The European quarter is the only decent part, the native quarter being very dirty.

The natives all seem to have donkeys, very small animals about 3'6" high which can carry very heavy loads in comparison to their size. Tis nothing to see a donkey coming along with a huge load up from under which all you can see is his head & legs. Also the men ride on top of this at times while the women carry great loads on their heads with the greatest of ease.
Entry.17:
Decided to take up signalling as I was tired of doing rifle exercises etc & accordingly entered the Signalling School which lasts 4 weeks & after which I go on to Big signalling school at Zeitoun for some weeks.

Saw Ainslie Kingsford one day he came down for the day from Kantara (about 25 miles up the Canal) where the L. Horse are camped at present.

I have been playing quite a lot of Rugby football since coming into details & am in the team representing the Details Camp. Have played against a Welsh team from the 53rdDivn, also a representative time from that Divn.

During the former game the rain simply poured down for about 20 mins & needless to say we got soaked which however did not prevent us from carrying on. This is the first rain we have seen since coming to Egypt.

Have played several matches against the N.Z.M.R. 

who are fine players indeed.
Entry.18:
Went up to Zeitoun today on a Signalling Course. Zeitoun is about 8 miles out of Cairo & quite close to Heliopolis. Zeitoun is about 90 miles from Ismailia.

A few miles from Moasen we began to come into the cultivated areas, which are irrigated from the main fresh water canal which follows the line & from which branches go out in all directions.

Their methods of irrigation are very rough but never the less effective. To raise the water from the canal onto the land, generally a height of 3 - 4 feet, they use two or three methods.

One method is to have a long pole pivoted on a perpendicular pole about 10 feet long. The top pole is so balanced by means of a weight of dried mud or something heavy on the end that when the bucket suspended on the other end is pulled down by the native & filled

the weight on the other end of the pole will raise it up. The native then emptiesit into his furrow & carries on again. This method is slow but time seems no object to them.
Entry.19:
Another method is to use a wheel (Horizontal) pivoted in the centre which is made to turn a wheel fitted with buckets on its rim, & fitted vertically against the other one. Pegs are used in place of cogs. As the Horizontal wheel is turned the pegs in it catch in those of the water wheel & thus turn it. As the wheel comes up & over the buckets empty into a trough. The flat wheel has an upright post about 3' high & from this a long pole about 12' long running out. A cow is hitched to this & made to walk around in a circle when it is required to raise the water.

On the rim of the vertical wheel is an endless chain of buckets. As the level wheel is turned the pegs on it interlace with those on the vertical wheel (like cogs) & so turn it. This type is generally used in wells etc for raising the water.
Entry.20:
Still another method is to get a cylinder about 8' long with a screw through it on the system of a corkscrew & turned by a handle at the top. One end rests in the water & the other empties into a furrow on top of the bank. These are very portable but slow.

The crops most in evidence at present are maize, sugar cane & some cotton. Saw some sheep with long tails & the wool of a dark brown colour. I should not think that the wool is of very good quality.

Cotton seems to be the main crop but as it is out of season at present have not seen any.

Their methods

of ploughing are very crude being the same as used thousands of years ago. It is drawn by 2 oxen, an ox & a camel or even by a single camel. The plough itself is of wood but some have an iron ploughshare. The handle is a single piece of wood about 3 feet long. 

The mainbar & the ploughshare are generally in one piece. As the soil in the Delta area is so very easy to work their ploughs are effective enough. They don't turn the soil over but simply tear through it.

Considering the primitiveness of their implements they achieve some good results. When ploughing is finished the natives go over the field with hoes breaking the clods.

About 30 miles from Moascar is Tel-el-Kebar which used to be the main Australian Camp prior to the infantry going to France. There were some thing like 100,000 men in March.

Tis now deserted but the miles of huts are still standing.

The Zeitoun School of Instruction is one of the biggest of its kind in the Empire. Some of its various branches are M. Gun training;N.C.O. course; Cadet course for officers; Cavalry school; Artillery & Signalling school; & Stokes Gun. This latter is a very portable French mortar which can fire up to 30 shots a minute with extreme accuracy up to 500 yds. In appearance it is just like a piece of drain pipe stuck on a bed or foundation & can be elevated as required.

The total strength of the schools was something like 2,000, one fifth or more of which were signallers.

The tucker is not nearly as good as at Moascar & leaves plenty of room for improvement.

We are quartered in huts made of light timber & boarded roofs not meant to keep the rain out. Each hut holds about 40-50 men.

Just a few minutes walk from the School is the big internment camp containing some 7 or 8 thousand prisoners of war of which the greatest majority are Turks. There are however some Austrians, Germans & Bulgarians.

The prisoners look very in their black woollen uniforms & red Fez caps & I don't think they would attempt to escape if given the chance even as they are so well treated. Tis a pity our prisoners are not treated as well in enemy countries.

We are about 7 miles from Cairo, the journey taking about 25 mins in one of the Electric railway cars or 10 mins by train from Helmiat stn. The fair on the tram is only½ PT
Entry.22:
Class.

Among the places that are very convenient for Soldiers are the Anzac Hostel & Esbekia Gardens. The former was the Bourse & is ideal for concerts & Picture shows etc, there being an entertainment

of some sort every night. Also there are Billiard Tables, writing & reading room, Restaurant & Bed Rooms. The Tariff is very moderate & a good meal can be obtained for 7 PT.

The leading Hotels, Sheperds, The Grand Continental & the National, are fine places but the 2 former ones are out of bounds to all troops except officers.

The pyramids can be seen quite plainly from the School - a distance of easily 15 miles. From Cairo out is an hours journey by tram costing only 1 PT which is about the cheapest tram ride that I have have yet had.

All the way out & running par'l to the tramline is a fine hard metal road shaded by big trees growing on either side. This road was built by Napoleon & along this the Society of Cairo goes for its evening Constitutional drive etc.

Tis not much good me giving any Statistics regarding the Pyramids I suppose as one can get them from anywhere.

The highest is 460', we did not go inside any of the Pyramids as tis not very pleasant nor did we climb any of them. To go inside you must take off your boots & slide down a low slippery passage.

The Sphinx is quite close to the Pyramids, in a hollow caused by excavations made to expose it. Its nose is broken off, done it is said by Napoleon in Battle of Pyramids.

The pyramids were covered at one time with a smooth coating of Limestone but all of this except a little on the centre one had been removed to build the Citadel.

Also visited the Museum. It is a fine building about 3 times as big as Sydney Museum, & is a 2 storeyed building.

It contains mostly relics of Ancient Egypt as mummies etc & would be very interesting to one who is a student of archaeology. Personally I found it rather dull.

The mummies are by far the most interesting. They are made by a process of pickling. The internal oragans are removed through the side & the brain is taken out through the nose. The body was then filled with rags etc to give it an appearance of fulness. It was then swathed in bandages with the hands crossed on the breast. The bodies were covered with hieroglyphics to keep out evil spirit & to preserve the body.

The Paprus of which there was quite a good deal is very old & was made from a reed of the same name. Some of the articles in the museum were over 4,000 years old.

Went to the Church at Heliopolis this morning
Entry.23:
Dec). It was a French Church (RC) & of unique architecture. It is very solidly built, of white stone with a small dome on each corner & a bigger one on the Centre of the roof.

The service was in French except of course the Mass which is in Latin & the choir consisted of French school boys. There is a service later in the morning in English for troops from the School of Instruction.

Returned to Moascar about a week before Xmas as the school broke up for a fortnight.

Saw a peculiar method of catching fish while down at Moascar this time. Onof the lake one day I saw a couple of boats containing natives who were stamping about trying to make as much row as they could. It seems that they had their nets on the surface of the

water, kept there by bamboo rods. The nets were placed in form of a circle inside which were the boats. The natives reckoned that by making such a row they would cause the fish to jump out of the water & so get caught in the nets if they failed to clear them.

Evidently they must have some success at this method or they would not use it. The fish caught this way were mostly mullet which do a lot of jumping.

Had sports on Boxing Day consisting of Athletic & Horse events. Came

Entry.27:
in Relay race.

Entry.28: The first few days of the New Year have been wet & bitterly cold.
Entry.29:
Des Mtd Corps had another sucess yesterday at Rafa, 32 miles up the coast from El Arish. 1,600 prisoners were taken with only 400 casualties on our side.

This Desert Mounted Corps is a mobile column consisting of Anzac Division, Imperial Division & the Camel Corps but was changed a few months later to the Anzac Div, Aust Div & Yeomanry Divn & Camel Corps.

Rafa was the occasion when mounted troops alone took a strongly fortified position. Prisoners have begun to arrive at the Prison Camp over the road 1,000 having so far arrived. They have been making an awful row since coming here & it may be because they have struck a

good home or because they have been telling the older men all the news. They have all been dished out with new uniforms.
Entry.30:
Went for a walk today to Makanich which is only a mile ot two from the School. Here we saw the Holy Well & the Virgins Tree where Joseph & Mary rested on their flight into Egypt.

There is a fine R.C. Church near by, on the inside walls of which are painted different events that occured during the flight.

About a quarter of a mile from the Church is the Old Obelisk which is said to be a sister one to Cleopatra's Needle. It is 40' high & has an equal length below ground. It was originally at Heliopolis but was moved to its present position to commemorate some great event in ancient history but exactly what that event was I do not know.
Entry.31: Wrote to Mr Elsworthy, the Red Cross Commissioner who is at Sheperds & had an answer today saying that he was going back to Australia in a couple of days time.
Entry.32:
Went out to the Citadel today. It is a fine place situated on the base of the Mokattam Hills overlooking Cairo & the River. The mosque is a beautiful place inside with something 5,000 lamps suspended inside from the roof. There are no seats inside or anything of that nature but just heavy carpet on the floor.

From the top of it you can get a fine panoramic view of Cairo. I took some snaps & for the one inside I had to give it 40 seconds exposure. Some chaps with me who had only singlelenses in their cameras had to give it as much as 90 seconds exposure.

At the back of the Citadel are the quarries from which the stone necessary to build the place was taken.
Entry.33: Had a game of football today with a team from Moascar, against the
Entry.34: Aus Camel Regt. Scores 8- 8. I scored for our side & next day was so stiff & sore that I could hardly walk - due to lack of condition.
Entry.35:
Went up to the Barrage last Sunday. This is a big dam built across a junction of the Nile about 15 miles above Cairo. The wall across the delta is about½ mile long, has sluice gates throughout its length & a few big towers at intervals.

The two branches are respectively 500 & 600 yards long with about 130 arches in all. Its object is the same as the big Aswan Dam but until a couple of years ago was not a success.

A light train line runs from the stn

to the dam, a distance of 2 miles. There are beautiful gardens here also a small museum containing working models of various parts of the works. To get some snaps of the wall we rowed out across the Dam. Had to take it in two sections.
Entry.36:
Sir Archibald Murray inspected the school today. The parade numbered about 2,000 in all & consisted of troops of all units on the front.

A few days ago wentover the road to the Aus Remount Depot to see a buckjumping exhibition. Tis easily the best exhibition I have ever seen & contains some of Australia's best riders.
Entry.37: Returned to Moascar. Details today & am going out to the Regiment in a day or so. The 42nd Divn is here now concentrating prior to going to France.
Entry.38:
Left Moascarat 10.20 for Kantara. Left Kantara at 1 oclock in open truck for the regiment. Detrained at Bir El Abd where we camped for the night. This is a watering place on the railway 45 miles beyond Kantara.

Next afternoon got horses which were brought in from the regt which is camped at a place called Bayud 7 miles out from Ber El Abd. The first chap I met from the Regiment was a chap named Thorpe who was at Hawkesbury in '15. Joined the Regimental signallers & was put on HQS.

At Bayud we go out on observation posts about 7 miles out, every
Entry.39:
day. We communicate by Helio.All supplies are brought out on camels which are the principal means of transport on the Sand. The water is always carried in metal cans called Fanates (?), shaped like a suitcase & of various sizes, & to contain 10, 12 or 15 gallons.

A camel generally carries two of these. The camp is situated on the sides of a hollow in the sand at the bottom of which are some date palms & a few wells & rising abruptly behind the trees is a huge sandhill.

The country is all sandy undulating hills covered with a coarse kind of vegetation which grows to a height of about 3 feet. This place was the scene of a scrap after Romani & our Regt did the stunt 20 miles & as they got no H2O when getting there & so had to go back.

Have been playing a lot of football here on the sand & it gets one in good condition. It has been very windy here during last few days & we cannot eat a meal on account of the sand blowing about. One day when we had just started dinner the tent blew down on top of us & spoilt our dinner.

Heard on
Entry.40:
that the Turks had evacuated a place called Shellal which was

supposed to be very strongly fortified.

This was an exceedingly favourable time for me to join the regiment as I had a month wherein to get used to the way of things while the regt is resting, before we start the actual campaigning again.

Moved over to another Hod. - Hod el Geeila, a distance of 7 miles, on
Entry.42:
we set out for El Arish.

Set out on
Entry.43:
en route to El Arish, following the old caravan route across the desert that has been in use for hundreds & hundreds of years. Only did 15 miles today & camped at a place called Tillul. Next day was only a short stunt - 8 miles to a place called Mazar which we reached by dinner time.

Set out next morning for Bardawal or Kilo 143 still following the old track & incidentilly the railway line. Arrived at 3 pm distance being 15 miles.

Travelled very quick today as we were going over a continuation of a dried salt lakes most of the way. The railway line is not very



Safe at present & there are breakdowns nearly every day on it. At Mazar took some snaps of a derailed engine.
Entry.44:
Left at 8.30 for El Arish travelling along the beach practically all the way. Passed our aerodrome at Kilo 143. Just as we got to El Arish orKilo 153 a Taube came over very high up & on being fired at by our anti aircraft guns turned & went back. I did not see the machine, as it was along way off.

We camped just over the railway line & about 200 yds from the sea. Went in swimming about 3 times a day & played football almost every afternoon. Went in swimming my horse one day with my watch on & of course the water got into it & rusted it.

The surf is not much good & there is also a fair amount of under tow. We have played the machine gun Squadron & Field Ambulance Combined, result 0 - 0. The complete
Entry.45: L H Bde is camped about here & consists ofthe 1st, 2nd & 3rd Regts, 1st L.H.F. Amb & 1st Machine Gun Squadron.
Entry.47:
had a Brigade Race meeting up the El Arish Wadi. It was very successful but the best event was the mule race. The mules were all shapes & sizes. The Bde Major won on a tiny mule & the Staff Capt came 2nd on a great big ungainly one.

We entered our mule for this, (Head Quarters Sigs Pack mule) but she followed a mule off the course about half way round. She has a head on her just like a tree. There were several impromptu bookies on the field & all of them did well.

5th

The
Entry.48:
Bde arrived today & are camped up the Wadi. They have been recently formed at the Canal & treeked up the desert. They consist of the 4th, 12th & 11th Regiments.

After a lot of chasing about saw Bob Stinson.

6th

Left at 8.30 for Shiekh Zoawide a distance of 21 miles arriving there about 4 pm.

Soon after leaving El Arish we began











to get into decent cultivated country & the going was much easier than further down the line. Saw plenty of small patches of cultivated land, some sown with bailey.

Left again next morning at 8.30 & just as we were moving out a Taube came over head flying low. We scattered but he did not drop any bombs. All the morning we travelled through good grazing country with plenty of crops about.

Crossed the Border into Palestine at 11.30 just near Rafa. Rode across the battle field which was now covered with crops which the Bedouins were harvesting. Halted at midday for lunch - our first meal in the land flowing with milk & honey which it certainly seems after the sand.Our horses appreciated the green crops very much as it was many a long day since they had had any.

Entered Khan Yunis about 3.30 & camped about a mile beyong it &

on the edge of the sand dunes which run along the coast all the way for a width of about 2 miles.

Khan Yunis is a small village with very narrow winding streets & mud huts. There is any amount of cactus about, it being used as hedges & fences. Khan Yunis is at the entrance of a valley which looks just lovely at present being covered with almond orchards & cultivated land.

A Taube came over very low on the afternoon of our arrival & to spite our antis, turned his machine gun on us without hitting anyone however.

Went out on outpost on our 2nd night here, for 24 hours. I was on an observation post all day with a Helio on a house top.

Saw a good air scrap today about half a mile away. A Hun tackled 2 of our machines from above & brought one of them down near the 2nd Regt.

From where we were we could just see into Gaza & during the day saw 6 of our planes bomb it, dropping about 40

bombs which we could see bursting.

Saw Jack Finn last night & had a long yarn to him. He is camped at Railhead which was shelled today by a Turkish high velocity gun. There were about 40 casualties.

Intended going to see Jack on Monday evening 17th but we left after tea for Shellal . The whole Division went out. Travelled all night & got to our destination just before day light next morning.

While watering in the wadi a Taube came over & bombed us, killing about 5 & wounding 20. I saw the bombs burst about 300 ydsaway.

The Anzac Divconsists of 1st & 2nd L.H. Bdes & N.Z.M.R.Bde, & 22nd Mtd Bde.

Went out same night about 8.30 & after travelling all night got into position next morning at day break at a place called Erk & went into action just about sunrise on a line of ridges which we held all day. We could have advanced but our

orders were only to hold the positions & not to attack.

I was with H.Q. & about a mile behind the line all day. They were shelling very constantly all day but did not do much damage around our quarters.

A Taube dropped a bomb about 50 yds away from where I was lying at the phone & burst about 5 yds away from the Brigadier & his staff (Col Cox) without hitting anyone.Just where we were - in a wadi was Bde H.Q.s, our led horses & the Field Ambulance.

During the afternoon a battery of Horse Artillery (18 pdns) the Leicesters galloped into action just about 100 yds away from us on an open piece of ground. They were quickly spotted by a Taube who dropped a smoke ball over them & in about 2 minutes they were being heavily shelled by Turkish Field Artillery. The shells were falling very close to us at times, some hitting the bank we were lying under,some were going over us & some just in front

but luckily none dropped in the wadi we were in.

It very quickly got too hot for the battery & they had to come out of action. it was great to see the way the teams came up at the gallop swing round limbered up & away in about 3 or 4 seconds, under heavy shell fire.All 6 guns were got away thus one at a time without a single casualty.

The Turks during the day had forced back the 2nd Bde on our right & towards evening were around the back of us & firing on us from behind so that under cover of darkness we cleared out.

During the afternoon the
Entry.50:
Regiments galloped out into action in front of us across the open ground. It was a grand sight to see the way they manouvered & opened out into close formation with the shells bursting among them. I reckon that it is a sight that will take some beating.

The Turks had a lot of calvary here & it was a Bde of these

that pushed back the
Entry.51:
Regt on our right.

The attack over Gaza way had not done well at all & at 3 pm the Turks counter attacked all along the line. Our casualties today all told were about 14,000. This could not be called a victory by any means & was a very servere knock back.

We travelled all night & just about daylight reached a position where I had been on outpost some days previous to the scrap, which was only 5 miles from Erk yet it took us all night to go there.We then turned in for a few hours much needed sleep as we hadhad none for 3 nights.

We were awakened at 8 am however & told to be ready to move in 15 min. Got saddled up & on the move & about 9 oclock as we were travelling along in close formation a Taube came along. As soon as he spotted us he turned & went home. About half an hour later 4 more came up one behind the other & dropped 16 bombs on us.



we did not have time to scatter & so just got off our horses & laid down as flat as one could get. Our casualties for the Bde were 75 horses killed, 5 killed & 30 wounded, some of whom died later on.

Just after the Huns went away, 6 of our machines went over laden with bombs, one of the Huns was circling above them but did not attack, nor did they molest him as they had bigger work on hand. We heard later on that they bombed a Turkish Cavalry Bde, dropping 54 bombs on them with excellent results.

These Taubs are the most demoralising things used, I think, as apart from the damage they do they play up with ones nerves so you see a plane above you & when he drops a bomb you hear it whistling of course & are sure that it is going to fall on you head.

Quite a lot of chaps get Taubitis. The Huns have some new machines now that are much faster than

ours.
Entry.52:
Coming in from outpost tonight we saw one of our machines that had been out bombing brought down &burst into flames on landing.

23rd.

Bombed again this morning (4 bombs) but no damage done beyond 2 men wounded &a couple of horses killed. Since we got cut up a few days ago, we adopt a new formation both when on the march & when bivouaced, called "Taube Formation".

The main idea is to keep as much distance as possible between troops thus presenting a Taube very poor target.

Have been issued with gas masks just before the stunt as preventitive against our own gas or the enemys. We fired some thousands of gas shells at Gaza but it was not effective as it was not concentrated enough.

Two of our tanks were put out of action at Gaza on
Entry.53:
one on top of tank redoubtwhere it still remains. It was through following the tank into action that 2 Companys of our Camel Corps were annililated on by above

7 men escaping. All the travelling is done at night now & only come home off a stunt in day time.
Entry.54:
Went out at 0330 this morning as Jacko wassuspected to make an attack. It did not come however & we had to ride back to camp. It is very hot & the dust of which there is a great deal makes ones mouth parched so that you drink far more water than you otherwise would &yet it does not quench the thirst. The dust gets in ones eyes also & at times you can hardly see out of them.

We have plenty of water when near the Wadi but very little when away from it as there is no means of getting it up.

Moved out same night for Shellal into a position we are to occupy for sometime. Camped just over the wadi about 100 yds from where the 2nd Bde were bombed on
Entry.55:
The horses have just been buried & the ground smells something awful at times when wind blows our way.

There is a plentiful supply in the wadi here, in fact all along it. This wadiGhuzze runs into the sea near Gaza & finishes up away down below Beersheeba. In winter it becomes a raging torrent but in summer just a chain of water hiles.

Just where we have our H.Q.s is a hill that we use as an observation post all day. On top is the remains of an old Christian Church. The floor is of beautiful mozaic work & was covered by 3 or 4 feet of earth.

The designs were made of variegated coloured stone & consisted of a Leopard, Flamingo, Vase of Fruit, Serpent, Goat & Peacock. There was some Greek writing which several officers tried to translate without much success.

Since we have been up on this hill I think every General & Staff officer on the front has been to see it. The whole floor has since gone back to Australia in a cement casting.
Entry.56:
Bombed again this morning, 4 horses killed & 2 men killed. We have antics

out here now which do some good shooting at times & keep the Huns well up at least.
Entry.57:
Huns made a moonlight raid last night, dropping about 40 bombs on a Hospital & Railhead. Their object was our aerodrome which they missed & got the hospital instead. There were about 40 casualties.

Next night they repeated the performance & 1 bomb alone killed & wounded 70 infantry. Same night one came along our way machine gunning our chaps who were digging trenches.

Today a Taube tackled 3 of our machines just out in front of us. One cleared off, one was brought down with a couple of bullets in his engine & a very light on fire. The pilot was burned badly but the machine was allright. The other machine hovered down low under cover of our machine guns, while the Hun circled above waiting for our machines to go up higher & yet afraid to come down on account of our machine guns. The machine was brought in during the night.

The Hun machine was much faster than ours & could manouvre with much greater ease.

Our patrol brought in 2 Turkish prisoners this morning (14th). They were quite young & rather good looking. They were armed with Mauser Rifles (1916 pattern) 120 rounds ammunition & a saw edged bayonet each. There clothes were exceedingly rough & coarse material.
Entry.58:
The 74th Divn have now taken over all the trenches we have been digging for the last month or so.

Moved yesterday up the wadi to a place called Hisea 1 mile from Shellal. The water we were using at the last place has now been marked cholera infected, which explains why we were all so sick at H.Q.s for a few days. For some days I used to vomit up all my meals as soon as I had had them & feel alright again afterwards, & quite prepared to eat another good meal.

Wind & dust have been very bad during last few days & absolutely get into everything. You cannot keep clean as if you have a wash you are just as bad again in 5 minutes time.
Entry.59: Left this afternoon on a long stunt to a place called Asluj some 15 miles below Beersheeba. Set out at 2 pm on
Entry.60: & did not get back to camp till midnight on
Entry.61:
riding practically all the time. We arrived at our destination at about 6 am next morning having covered about 43 miles.Going home however we went by a shorter route of about 37 miles. We must have travelled easily 80 miles on this stunt.

Met with practically no opposition except for some shots fired at us by Bedouins of whom we saw a fair number.

We blew up a long railway bridge over a wadi at Asluj station. The Bridge has 15 spans in it & was well made of sandstone. We also blew up some miles of railway with gun cotton.

Quite near the station was a village that had probably been used as a frontier post as it contained a big barracks that had been used by cavalry. The line was narrow gauge about 3'6" & ran from Beersheeba to a place called

Ajua on the Border of Palestine & Sinai. It could be used as a jumping off ground for an attack on our communications at El Arish, say, as it is only about 40 miles from Ajua to El Arish. Altogether 20 miles of line & several bridges were destroyed.

We were on the extreme right of the whole force & while we were blowing up the line the other troops were making a feint attack on Beersheeba to distract attention from us.

The camel corps were down below us atAjua & were out for some days altogether.There were nearly 25,000 mounted troops on this stunt consisting of the Anzac Divn, Imp Mtd Divn & Camel Corps.

At 10 oclock the whole of Desert Column retired but we did not get home till midnight. We were awfully done up when we got home & it was easily the longest ride that ever I had done.

For the last 10 miles or so I could not sit in one position in the saddle for more than 5 minutes as I was so sore. To add to our miseries we got lost after dark & I am almost sure we passed one certain hill 3 times.

I slept until dinner time next day.

Managed to get several snaps of the bridge, one before it went up, 1 as it was going up & one after the explosion.

We saw quite a lot of sheep in one flock we counted over 300 & also got plenty of fowls & eggs.

On the way home we burnt a tremendous quantity of hay.
Entry.62: Went back about 6 miles today for a spell of 9 days in reserve & 9 on the beach.
Entry.63: of our planes chased & brought down a Hun. Two more today chased another one & only for the machine gun jamming would have brought it down. This is a welcome sign as it seems as ifwe are getting our own back a bit.
Entry.64:
Went down to the beach today for a swim & gave the horses one also.

Some French Colonials at Khan Yunis as we were going through. They come from Morocco. They are very smart & have a good turn out. I don't think there is more than about a Battalion of them here at present. There are also some Italians here too about 1 Battalion. They are "Bersaglient"
Entry.65: Was playing football yesterday against the
Entry.66:
Regt & during the game I received a kick on the right knee which necessitated me going to hospital next day.

Went from our Field Ambulance to a Divisional Clearing Stn & from there on to a Field Hospital at Rafa where Istayed 2 days. The journey to Rafa was over rough ground & the swaying of the Ambulance made me quite sick.

I was still Capt of the Regiment team & was rather unlucky in getting hurt when I did as our Bde went down to the beach for 10 days the next day after I left the Regt & I was looking forward so much to this trip.

Went down to El Arish in a hospital train today
Entry.67:
Stayed the night there in No 2 Aus Stn Hopl & next morning went down to Kantara to No 24 Stationary Hospital.

Had to wait here a few days before I could get on to the
Entry.68:
A.G.H. at Cairo.

My knee is doing well now & is nothing very serious just a slight touch of synovitis. Don't like this Hospital at Kantara at all & will be glad to get under

our own people.
Entry.69: Left Kantara this morning at 8.30 in a fast hospital train & was in Cairo about 12.30. This is a beautiful train & they look after you very well on it.
Entry.70:
Sick of being kept in bed & am to be allowed up tomorrow, I hope. The nights are very warm now & one does not need any bed clothes at all. They treat us very well in here & the nurses are kindness itself. The thing I appreciate most of all are the baths & that one can keep clean.Also you soon get rid of all septic sores, which I was never without at the regiment.

The
Entry.71:
AGH is a fine big building of 2 storeys & built on square system with a big quadrangle in the middle. Twas originally built by Napolean for barracks & is crest is still on the top of the main gate. The walls are remarkably thick - about 3' at least & running down the centre of the wards & supporting the roof are big pillars about 3'6" square & one every 7 or 8 yards.

There is a namesake of mine in Hospital

at present (but no relation) a Lieut McNamara from the 67th AFC who has the VC & is wounded. He landed in the Turkish lines & brought away the pilot of one of our machines that had been brought down.
Entry.73:
for Montazal Convelecent home, a few miles out from Alexandria & near Aboukir Bay. Tis a fine place - the Harem of the Sultan of Egypt before the war & now the Red Cross Convalescent Home. It is absolutely ideal for a convalescent home & is situated round the shores of a small bay that has only a small entrance & exit.

There are about 1,400 patients here at present about 100 of whom are Australians. The Block I happen to be in was donated by the Lismore District farmers. There are numerous buildings here which are used as wards & about 100 acres of fruit trees & woodlands.

The Bay is an ideal place for swimming, it being about 600 yds across to the breakwater where the water is as clear as crystal. A young Scotty & myself used to go over to the Breakwater for a

couple of hours every day.

There is a sailing boat here also & several rowing boats. We are not allowed outside the breakwater however. There is a certain amount of fishing done also but the fish are not very plentiful. Also have tennis courts & cricket pitches & I generally have a couple of sets of Tennis everyday.

We have concerts a couple of times a week as well as open air pictures. The tucker here is great, much better than in hospital & we have 4 meals a day.

Have a fortnight here & good as it is it will be long enough for me as it gets monotonous. When we first arrived we thought we could easily do a couple of months in such a fine place but itsoon wore off & when I left on
Entry.74:
was not altogether sorry to be going.

Went back to Moascar today,
Entry.75:
arriving there at about 10 pm that night.

The Last of Ramadan has just finished & now the natives are having 5 days feasting to make up for what they have lost in the past

month. During the month of Ramadan the Egyptans fast from 3 in the morning until 7 pm at night. They take it very seriously & the greater majority of the natives keep the fast which is more than I could do I am sure.

Fasting is one of the 5 main points of their religion & Mahomedans adhere very strictly to the laws of their religion.
Entry.76:
Was innoculated this morning and has 2 full doses, 1of cholera & 1of Para Typhoid, receiving 1 in each arm. Was rather unwell during the day & was very feverish over night & my arms were very sore & stiff next day.

25th

Got a new rig out this morning as I am going back to the regiment today.

Saw Bob Stenson today for a while, he is in details at present. He was very confident of getting his Commission as a pilot in the Sqdn. He was looking very well & had much benefited by his sojourn in Hospital & at Montazah.

Went to Kantara by the afternoon train & left same night at 10 pm in a troop train. We were jammed in like flies, 35 men



per truck. This is the hottest period of the year & as we are pretty soft after coming out of hospital we feel the heat.

When we got to Rafa at 10 am next morning we had to march about 2 miles through heavy sand to a rest camp. We were just like wet socks when we got there & completely knocked up. We have to stay here 24 hours & go back to the regiment tomorrow.

Had a good nights rest after the weary train journey & next morning marched back to the Station with ourkit up & 120 rounds of ammunition.

It was the hotest part of the day & we were wringing wet when we got to the Station. Got a train out to Shellal at dinner time & there we were met by men from the Rgt with horses which was camped about 5 miles away.

They have been having a very rough time out here lately & I am not sorry to have missed it.

Ex Capt Downs who was at Menangle in my time is over now & came out to join the 7thRegt today as a trooper as he could not come away with a commission.

We adopt a new formation when camped now (3 Sqdns)being in the shape of a hollow square, a squadron forming a side of it & HQ's & Sigs etc the remaining side of it,there being 3 squadrons in the Regiment. This formation presents an exceedingly small target to the Hun planes & tis a mere fluke if he does any damage,

30th

We are in some redoubt at present X, Y & Z covering the extreme right flank of our line. The redoubts are about¾ of a mile apart & at the rear of them we have the horse lines.

Tis 3 miles from here to water in the wadi which is too far to go down & back twice a day so when the horses go down in the morning one man to 3 horses, the men take their dinner & after watering go out beyond the wadi grazing on the plain until about 2.30 when they come back & water.

There are 4 sigs here so that we only have to go down every fourth day, as one man takes our 4 horses.

We are to occupy these redoubts for a week at the end of which we will be relieved by another Regiment.

We have had a lot of reinforcements now on this front of men & guns & now have 7 infantry Divisions here the 10th 52nd 53rd 54th 60th 74th & 75th & 3 mounted Divisions forming the Desert Mounted Corps. The Inf Divns are grouped into 2 Army Corps the
Entry.78: There must be something like 25,000 men on this front now with about 800 guns.
Entry.79: Have been back some days now from the Redoubts & have been on a couple of all night stunts out beyond the wadi, on one of these we ran into a Turkish redoubt before we knew it was there. The enemy opened a heavy fire but no one was hit.
Entry.80:
Regiment went over to Shellal Junct today to be deloused. They have a disenfecting train into which we put all our blankets & clothes for half an hour to be steamed & disenfected. While this is on you have to wear an overcoat or anything you like. The clothes are wet when they come out but very quickly dry on



your body.

Heard a few days ago that the Mooltan was sunk off Gibraltar on
Entry.81: by a mine, was very sorry to hear this.
Entry.82:
Went out on a stunt last night to a place below Beersheeba . We travelled all night, covering at least 25 miles & just after daylight got onto a hill 3 miles from Beersheeba . We had a rotten journey as we seemed to be stopping every quarter of an hour or so & we would no sooner lay down than we would have to go on again. I was with "C" Sqdn for this stunt & not with HQ's.

We crossed the Beersheeba Agua railway & went about a mile or so beyond it onto Hill 1160. We were engaged with the enemy at long range with machine guns & rifles.

C Squadron was out in front today & was doing the scrapping. About 8 am they started to shell us from a hill about 2 miles in front of us & in about 2 minutes everyone was off the Hill with the exception of my mate & myself.

The first 2 shells lobbed about 10 yds away but hit no one.



I was sending a message on the helio at the time & did not notice anything until they were all gone. The chap who had our horse did not stay with them, but cleared out. We had all our gear off our horses, including the packhorse & were just having breakfast when they started.

We got away eventually & I handed the message in when I got in to H.Q's, as I did not finish sending it. I did not get any breakfast however.

When our men left the hill the enemy lengthened his range & got onto the Sqdn as they were going back across the plain to H.Q. They had a couple of men killed, 2 wounded & some horses killed.

We brought home about 20 Bedouins who had been firing on us. They were armed with Turkish Rifles of new pattern (1916).

We travelled about 50 miles on this stunt but it was worse than that of May 22nd owing to the heat & because we had no water & I had nothing to eat all day.

Could not see Beersheeba owing to intervening hills. Got home on night of
Entry.84:
on same stunt only our Regt was in reserve to the Bde.The other two Bdes 2nd & NZMR were on our left.

General Allenby was out today having a reconnaisance of the country & was accompanied by General Chauvel, Gen Chaytor (Anzac Divn) & our Brigadier Gen Cox. They came out all the way in motor cars of which there were 13 including a few armoured motor cars. They went back before dinner having had a good look round.

The
Entry.85:
Regt went up to where we were shelled a couple of days previously & did not have a shell fired at them.

Went backhome by a short cut & got back to camp about 8 pm. We are going down to the beach on
Entry.87: Outpost tonight & day patrol tomorrow morning.
Entry.88: We were not relieved until dinner time by the
Entry.89:
Mtd Bde (London Rough Riders) & did not get to the beach until 7.30 pm.



Rode about 20 miles that day, we watered at Shellal crossing on way back & noticed the wonderful improvements that had been made since we were there last time 3 months ago.

There is a big railway bridge over the wadi, also a traffic bridge for the wet season & a big dam, with a pumping plant on the bank of the water. Also they have big stone troughs there now for watering horses & the water laid on by pipes from the dam.

At the beach we are camped only 20 yds from the waters edge & are always in swimming. The whole Divn is scattered along the beach for about 4 miles. We get water for the horses by simply digging in the sand about 18" when we get a plentiful supply of fresh water.
Entry.90: Was called up tonight by the Colonel & told that I had been awarded the Military Medal for the stunt on the
Entry.91:
I got an awful shock & you could have knocked me down with a feather as I never dreamt for a

minute that I had been recommended & in fact had expected to be "for it" for not finishing the message. I certainly don't think I deserve it.
Entry.92:
Received a letter of congrats today from Gens Chauvel & Chaytor & a piece of ribbon. Sent this home as it would only have got soiled & dirty.

We were inspected today by Gen Chaytor Divn Commander & I had to brighten up our bits & stirrup irons for it. We cleaned them in the sand but they were just as bad again in a couple of days.

The
Entry.93:
Bde have just completed a Boxing Tournament which was very successful though there was not much talent there. Brig Gen Ryrie was referee & gave very good decisions. He is an ex-Champion amateur & knows a lot about the game.

Our Bde starts a tourament tomorrow.
Entry.94: A lot of the horses are getting sand colic, other wise they are doing pretty well. To prevent them eating sand we have muzzles for them now.
Entry.95:
Inspected by Gen Chauvel today & of course had to clean our bits & stirrup irons again but they did not get much polishing.

Our Boxing Tourmament lasted 2 nights but did not bring forth any white hopes etc. Perhaps the good men did not care to enter or else there is not much boxing talent among the L. Horse.

We had a Brigade Sports meeting on
Entry.96:
The main item of interest was a challenge race for £100 aside between 2 men of our Bde. One of them a Queenslander named Schoeler won easily by 6 yds,

Afterwards the same man won practically everything in the Bde Championships including the 75 yds Chmps 100 yds; 220, hop, shin & jump, high jump, & long jump & won about£22 in prize money apart from his share of the£100 stakes. The stakes were raised by the men & officers of the regiment but I think he would get about£25 out of it.

At the finish they had a mule race

which was exceedingly funny. Everyone was doing their best to frighten the mules & they were going everywhere. A very small mule won it.
Entry.97:
Left the beach this morning for a new camp on the railway line from Rafa to Shellal. We were not altogether sorry to leave the beach as though we had had a good months rest we were beginning to get a bit tired of it.

One never seems to be content in the Army & we do not like to get stuck in one place for any length of time & yet we don't like the actual move.

Our new camp is on an open plain the soil of which is a sandy loam & is very quickly churned up by the horses hoofs.

Prior to our occupation in April the country was under crop & heavily grassed, but now all vistage of crop etc is gone & the top few inches of surface soil has been churned into fine dust.

A strong wind blows in from the sea every afternoon after dinner & when the horses go to water they raise clouds of dust which spreads all

over the plain, you cannot see 50 yds ahead of you when going to water & the dust gets down your nose & through parching you & fills your eyes & ears up.
Entry.98:
Our horses were out grazing today on the hills just to the west of the camp & something caused them to stampede. Away they went full gallop through the camp & away beyond it.

They were eventually pulled up about 2 miles from camp & 3 managed to break their necks. Twas a surprise to us as we did not think our horses had a gallop left in them.

All Regiments are being issued with 24 donkeys each now owing to lack of remounts. None have come over for 3 months & no more are expected until the end of this month.
Entry.99:
Went to 67th Sqdn AFC today as a wireless operator. I have been after this for some time now & passed my test when down on the beach. I rank as 2 AM & pay is increased to 8/- per day.





5/- of which I must allot. Hope to stay in the aerodrome for a couple of months & have an easy time.

Things are much more comfortable in here at the aerodrome than in the L Horse & the men have tents to sleep in (4 per tent) & also mess huts (marquees) for meals. By putting in 10 PTS each per pay we can get a lot of extras in grub & at least can have a pudding every day.
Entry.100:
There was an air scrap this morning but on account of it being up in the sun we could not see it, but could hear the machine guns easily enough. It appears that 2 of our machines tackled 2 Huns. One cleared off home while the other stayed.

The one that stayed was brought down in our lines with holes through his engine & petrol tank.It was an Albatross Scout & the pilot was captured uninjured & the machine was intact.

One of our machines was badly knocked about & had trouble in reaching the drome.

This scrap caused great excitement & rejoicing as it was the first Hun machine to be brought down in our lines.

Both pilot & his machine were brought into our drome & the machine is being repaired preparatory to flying it. The pilot, a Prussian named Ober-Lieut Dietmach, was not a bad looking chap.

He mounts two machine guns on his machine synchronised to the engine & crossfiring in front about 300'. He uses armour piercing & tracer bullets. These tracer bullets are coated with phosthorus whichcatches alight when going through the air & will set a machine on fire if it hit it in a suitable place.

The pilot had hard luck as he had been in this country for 3 years & was going home to Germany in a few days time, on leave.
Entry.101:
Our fighters brought down another Hun Scout today. He surrended when he saw that he was outclassed but instead of landing in our

lines as our pilot signalled him too, he kept heading for his own lines, so our machine emptied his machine gun into him at very close range & he dropped like a stone. The pilot was unrecognisable & his machine was smashed to atoms.

The air service here is improving now & we have some fine new fighting machines here - Bristol Fighters.

We have 4 Squadrons on this front now, 113 RFC (just lately come) 111 RFC (Fighting Squadron)
Entry.103:
Sqdns do artillery co-operation work, 111ththe fighting & escort work & our Sqdn does bombing, reconnaisances & photography.

Our Squadron has done more flying than any other here by a long way.
Entry.104:
Went out today to Shellal to join 181 HeavyBattery RGA in 96th Heavy Group, as wireless operators attached to the battery. There was another chap with me who was in charge.

Thus my dreams of staying in the aerodrome for a couple of months was

rudely shattered. Our station is very portable & can be erected or dismantled in 15 or 20 minutes. It consists of a Short Wave Tuner MK111, 2 poles 20' high & an aerial of copper wire 60 yds long suspended between the two poles. This aerial wire is connected to our instruments.

Also we have 2 copper mesh mats about 12' long & 2' wide which we cover with earth & connect by a lead to our instrument.

We have a Bivoy made made in 1 piece which is much better than anything that the troops are issued with. We generally pitch the bivoy at the foot of the taller mast & have our aerial pointing in the direction the guns are going to shoot, as a rule.

Also as part of our equipment we have 6 canvas strips 13' x 2' which we use for signalling to the aeroplanes from the ground. Our instrument is simply for the receiving & we cannot transmit messages.

Our station when in action will be pitched about 100 - 200 yds to the rear of the guns. We have horses to ride & they are easily the two biggest crocks in the battery. One - mine, has a reputation as a buck jumper but when I got on him he did not do a thing.

This battery has just come from Salonika where they were for about 9 months. They have 4 guns, 60 pounders eaching weighing about 7 tons when ready for travelling & with an extreme range of 13,500 yds(Once however we by digging in the trail got as much as 14,500 yds on) but the gun was sticking up just like an anti air craft gun.

The guns are drawn by horses, a gun team consisting of 14 heavy draught horses but when we had been on the move sometimes these were reduced to 10 or 12.

In the group towhich we are attached are 2 seige batteries of 6" Howitzers, 2 batteries of 60 pounders & a battery of 4.5" Howitzers.

Since we joined them we have had a couple of test shoots to see if the guns have the right mixture in the recoiling chambers. On the
Entry.105: test the guns were jumping something awful but were allrightthe
Entry.106: time, as the oil in the buffers had been thickened in the meantime by the addition of some glycarine.
Entry.107: Moved to Gamli a place in the Wadi just below Tel-el-Fara. We are going out any day now as the big stunt is starting soon. Our Heavy group is going to Beersheeba . There is great movement of troops now - getting ready for the attack.
Entry.108:
Moved out last night to a position 13 miles from Fara & 5 from Beersheeba .

Got into position about 3 am put our stn up & then turned in for a sleep until 6 am when the attack started. We bombarded all day long on various targets as Batteries etc but mostly on redoubts & trenches. Just about dusk & after a couple of hours

bombardment a general attack was made on the place by infantry in front & the Des Mounted Corps in the rear. The infantry were just getting held up on the
Entry.110:
L H Bde charged at full gallop over the trenches right into the middle of the town.

After this the Turks threw in & the town was ours. We captured about 2,000 men 20 guns & thousands & thousands of rounds of small arms & shell ammunition.

It was absolutely necessary to take the place on the first day as all the troops were depending on it for their water supply. We did excellent work at Beersheeba & put a couple of batteries out of action.

The enemy must have got a big surprise when our heavy guns opened out as he never dreamt that we could get our heavy guns up during a night. We had about 220 guns of all calibres concentrated on Beersheeba that day & the heabier did by far the most damage.

We did not enter Beersheeba but went next morning to a place about 6 or 7 miles to the left of Beersheeba & on the line to Gaza, over very heavy & rough country.

Got into position about 4 pm & found that there was no infantry in front of us. We could see troops moving about at Irgig stn only 2 miles in front of us & thought they were our own.

The 10th Div was supposed to have been in front of us but did not arrive until just about dusk so that we had to withdraw our guns about 2,000 yds. Rather a peculiar position to be in for a Heavy Battery to be out in front of infantry but of course it was an unusual occurence.

Next morning, November
Entry.111:
we had to go back to Karm 8 miles as our horses had had no water for over 48 hours & were nearly done. We were in just as bad a plight & could get only about a pint of water a day.

The 10th Div took Irgig this morning without much opposition.



They had not been in Beersheeba stunt & had marched up from Rafa which accounted for them being so late.

Went back to Karm to give horses a few days spell but did not take the guns down.

On
Entry.112:
went back up to our guns setting out at about dinner time. After limbering up, the guns went on further, crossed the railway line at Irgig & got into position eventually about 3 am in the morning only¼ mile beyond the railway.

Had to put our station up as we were to start early. Had a little breakfast about4.30, - the first bite we had had since the previous morning.

We opened fire at sunrise & continued until 9.30 am when we advanced the guns about 1¼ miles to a position they had taken earlier in the morning. During the day there was some severe fighting at places & about 400 prisoners & 4 guns were taken with some machine guns.

After tea we went up 2

miles further. Got into position about 10 pm put ourstation up & turned in. On the way up we saw a big Turkish ammunition dump going up at Sheria .

Early this morning 7th we were in the bombardment & barrage on Sheria which it was necessary for us to take as it contained an unlimited water supply. The place was taken after very violent hand to hand fighting about 8 am.

Advanced again at 11 am about 1½ miles & got into a position about 2 miles from Sheria.

The L Horse (Aus Divn) went through this morning & are following up the retreating turks. They captured 2 5.9" Howitzers this morning absolutely intact.

The plan now seems to beto swing round north of Gaza & envelope it as we have broken his C centre at Sheria while Beersheeba settled his right flank.

There was a combined army & navy bombardment of Gaza for 3 days but

not much fighting there.

The Turks evacuated Gaza during the night of the
Entry.113:
& got most of his stuff away. He left some thousands of rounds of ammunition both small arms& shells which he could not get away. If he had stayed in Gaza a day longer he would have been cut off which would have meant some thousands of men & guns surrendering.At Scheria we captured intact a Turkish hospital.

As we have been exceedingly short of water during the last few days I went over to Sheria wells last night
Entry.114:
with one of the Signallers taking about a dozen water bottles between us. I did not know where Scheria was as I had not seen the place in daylight & so had to trust myself to the Tommy & coming home we got lost completely. About midnight we struck a field hospital & stayed there until daylight when we found ourselves only½ a mile away from the battery.

This was the first occasion on which I

had ever been lost. There is an unlimited supply of water at Schenia which was a god send to us.

The infantry are now 7 miles beyond Sheria & the L Horse nearly 20 miles. The enemy is retreating very fast so that we cannot keep up with our heavy guns - on
Entry.115:
we went through Sheria & camped about a mile beyond it & only a couple of hundred yards from a Turkish field battery which had been captured intact.

Had a good look round as there were any amount of stuff lying about a general dump in war. We are supposed to be here for 48 hours rest.

There are any amount of dead lying about & they are all swollen & black from the sun.

The battery near us had been taken at the point of the bayonet as the dead gunners were lying near the guns. They were mostly Austrians but some were Turks. 5 of them were still alive & had been laying there unattended for 3 days.

They were removed during the night to a Field Hospital for wounded Turks at Sheria.

There were hundreds of rifles & bayonets lying about including some saw edged ones. Also there were German Gas masks, Packs, eating implements, dishes etc & all kind of uniforms & clothing lying about.Every one was collecting souvenirs & needless to say I was one of them. The Infantry had got the best however as they were first in there.
Entry.116:
Word came through about 2 am this morning that we are to go back to Karm which will certainly spoil our 48 hrs rest.We cannot follow up in pursuit & so are going back for a spell to Karm which is 17 miles from here by road.

As we went through Sheria on our way back we saw about 500 prisoners including a General going back. They are an awful looking lot of men but some of them are of fine phisique.

We have not been doing well for grub lately, as the Q Master
