generally manages to get lost when going for rations & one night was going up to the front line for them until he was stopped. He was in the army 26 years & I reckon he is in his
Entry.117:
childhood.They bluff him at the dumps & whereas other people get break every day he brings back biscuits for this battery.

We went back 7 miles to Irgig today & go the remaining 10 to-morrow.

We had our horses taken away from us on the
Entry.118:
& so we refuse to walk the rest of the way. They left the guns at Irgig for a well & we stayed with them & had a very easy time with nothing to do & heaps of water only¼ mile away in the wadi.

On
Entry.119:
the guns went down to Karm where the remainder of the 96th H.A.G. was concentrated. We went down but did not walk, as we rode on the waggons.

Had a good spell at Karm as there were anyamount of canteen about & so we lived well for the 10 days

we were at Karm. Received a big mail also at Karm the first we had had for almost 2 months.
Entry.120: Got on the move again today our ultimate destination being Ramleh or Jaffa. We went across to Sheria & then along the Beersheeba road to Gaza. Did not enter the town however but went a few miles in rear of it onto the main road going up the coast. The Turkish railway starts about 4 miles beyond Gaza & runs parl to ours, which is now 16 miles beyond Gaza. We travelled 7 miles the first day, 16 the
Entry.122:
day, 20 on the 4th.

Passing along the road is a never ceasing stream of motor lorries & light Ford cars, carrying up supplies etc.

There are villages every 4 or 5 miles along the road but are very dirty & squalid. Oranges are very plentiful now & cost 1 piastre for 6 = approx 3 for d.The country we are passing through is very level, rich & well cultivated.

Up at the front now they are not making much progress owing to lack of Heavy artillery which is now being rushed up.
Entry.123: Arrived at Junction Station today after only a 6 mile stunt. This is our
Entry.124:
day on the march. This place is the Junction for all the lines from Jaffa, Jerusalem & Gaza.

There were several fine buildings here which are now being used by us as Hospitals. An enormous quantity of building material was captured here some thousands of pounds worth, also some engines & rolling stock.The engines were all made in Belguim.

We are now about 34 miles beyond Gaza by road & during the whole of the treck of 55 miles we have only walked about 5 miles. The remainder of it we rode in cars or motor lorries. Our plan was to find the days destination then get in a motor car & go on ahead & wait for them or if we did

not know exactly where they were going so we went about 6 miles ahead & waited for them at a village. We found no difficulty in getting a ride as there are motors passing continually day & night.

Some some chaps from the 1st Regt today & had a long yarn to them. The Regt has been cut up during the stunt & has so far had about 120 casualties.

Ainslie Kingsford has a commission now.
Entry.125:
Went on to Naanch today 5 miles beyond Junction & only 3 from Ramleh we are to camp here some days & then go into action just out beyond Ludd.

To celebrate my 21st birthday on
Entry.126:
only had Bully & biscuits. It had been very cold here during past few days & raining almost continuously.

Went into Ramleh one afternoon & had a good look around. It is a fair sized place of about 4,000 inhabitants & has some decent buildings in it. It has plenty of shops etc but they do not contain much.

One building which used to be Turkish GHQ has a tall spire on it with a clock on each side of its 4 sides. Also in the town is an old tower the remains of an early Christian Church. At the foot of it are some underground chambers extending for some considerable distance, which I did not explore however.

Surrounding the town are about 40 acres of almond orchards. A great deal of the land around here has been ploughed quite recently. The methods of ploughing are the same as back in Egypt & are very primative.

On the afternoon of the
Entry.127:
it fined up & we moved up to a position about 3 miles out from Ludd. The roads are so bad - just like quagmires that our guns were getting stuck everywhere. Were getting stuck everywhere.

The distance was only 7 miles but at 3 am next morning we were still a couple of miles short with 3 guns stuck along the road & the 4th upside down

at the foot of a bank. It was bitterly cold during the night & we were thankful that it did not rain which would have only added to our trouble.

Next day with the help of 100 men from the Essex Regt we managed to get the gun on to its wheels again & onto the road. It was undamaged luckily.The same night we went on & got all 4 guns into position before next morning.

Jerusalem was occupied on the
Entry.128:
& now our troops are some miles beyond it.

We were paid in notes a few days ago but they are useless. As we cannot get any change & if you want to buy anything you have to get 50 PT worth & share it around among several others who do the same thing in turns.

Whatwe mostly buy is Jewish bread which is brown in colour, very open texture & costing 1/- per 1lb loaf. Also we can buy oranges & Turkish tobacco which is not much chop as it is too green.
Entry.129:
Moved up 2,000 yds further today as we were out of range almost, our extreme range is 13,500 yds for which the trail of the gun must be tug down considerably to get the gun elevated to 30º or 32°.We can see Jaffa quite distinctly from here it lying across the plain 12 miles away.

Our advanced section who are about a mile in front of us were shelled one morning for 2 hrs & had to move a few hundred yards.
Entry.130:
It has been raining for last few days, intermittently. There was a very heavy bombardment last night over on the coast sector in which the navy participated.

We advanced some miles this morning capturing some hundreds of prisoners & the village of Mulebis .

Had an issue of Australian butter (¼ lb each) today in lieuof bacon & also rabbits, we get these twice a week now & this will continue throughout the winter.
Entry.131:
Last night it simply poured for 3 hours or more & about 1 am our Bivvy which was situated

in a wadi was flooded out. The water had been damming up at the back of it for some time & when it burst a torrent of water came rushing through the bivvy.

All I had time to grab was my breeches & cardigan jacket. Everything else was soaked including blanket, overcoat, tunic etc. My mate was just as badly off. He managed to get into a bivvy with some chaps until morning but I sat shivering in the Command post until day light.

Had no chance to dry anything as it rained during the daywe could not even find a dry place to pitch our bivouac. During the afternoon we moved up into some caves on the side of the hill that our guns were below.

We lit a fire in here to try & dry our clothes but the smoke could not get out as there was only one entrance & it faced the wind so that we were nearly suffacated.

Had to sleep the night there without anyblankets but it was dry which was some consulation.

There had been a general retirement by the enemy for the last couple

of days for about 5 miles & we are hardly in range now.
Entry.133: was the most miserable one that it has so far been my lot to experience. It rained all day practically & was very cold besides & we have had no mail since leaving Karm.Had bully & biscuits for dinner today.
Entry.134:
It fined up yesterday so we got a chance to dry our clothes & blankets etc & do some much needed washing.

Rations are very short now owing to the railway line having been washed away & to the transport difficulties. The roads from here into Ludd are simply quagmires & the waggons have great difficulty in getting through it.

The roads can not really be called such as they are just tracks across ploughed land which is very soft & of a clay nature. It retains the water which gathers in great pools.

About 15 men slept in our cave last night but it was too many as there is no ventilation in

it though there was room enough for 20 men.

There are a lot of bugs in these caves which bite during the night & suck blood out, leaving a great black mark about the size of a three penny bit. Several of the chaps got covered with these, including my mate but I did not get any of the bites luckily.

We got out of the cave today
Entry.135:
& pitched our bivvy under a tree on top of the hill.

On
Entry.136:
we left for a position up the coast beyond Jaffa. To go to it across country would have only been about 7 miles, but we had to go round by the road to Ludd & Jaffa, as it was to boggy going across the plain.

Camped 3 miles on the Ludd side of Jaffa the first day on the main road from Jaffa to Jerusalem. To get to this we had to get through some awful mud & slush but from now on the way will be much easier.

Next morning
Entry.137:
we pressed on passing through Jaffa, without stopping or having a chance to see anything of it. The country around Jaffa is very rich & covered with orange

orchards. I have never yet seen oranges so prolific as in this locality & we no longer buythem as we can have them for the taking.

There are thousands of troops billeted in Jaffa which would bevery comfortable over the winter.

This quite a treat to see European women again with their nice white clear skins & decent clothing which makes a pleasant contrast with the native women.

The Europeans are mostly Jews & some are Germans there being a big German colony only a few miles north of Jaffa.

There are some nice buildings in the town & the streets are very clean, being cobbled & the footpaths asphalted.

Went about 5 miles beyond the town & halted until sunset as we could not go the remaining 3 miles into our position until after dark. We got into position about 9 pm & turned in.The last 5 miles was through very heavy sand & our horses were absolutely done.

It took 44 of them to pull one gun into its position whereas at ordinary times 12 could do it easily.

This position is in the middle of an orange grove flanked on one side by almond orchards extending to the right for some hundreds of acres & on the other side by a Eucalyptus grove. These tress had all been imported from Australia & were being laid out in groves.

In front of the guns, about a mile, is the Jewish colony & village of Mulebis .

There are any amount of oranges to be had, just for the picking of them & we don't stint our selves either. All the orchards are irrigated during the summer months as it is so dry then & the soil retains no moisture so that the trees would soon die.

The water is stored in huge wells about 60' deep. The side of these have to be bricked to prevent them from falling in. The water is raised from these wells by means of pumping plants which are very numerous & it is distributed over the land by means

of pipes. Most of the pumping plants were rendered useless by the retreating turks who took away some of the necessary parts. All these engines were of English manufacture.

Went up into the village today
Entry.138:
& was rather disappointed in it. It is a scattered place nearly all the houses being made of wood. Some however being made of stone with either wood or tile roofs.

The people are all Jews & the universal language among them is German while only a few speak French. We can but quite a lot of things in there as dates, nuts, candles etc but everything is very dear. Change is very plentiful however which is quite a surprise to us.

I got into conversation with one chap who had travelled a good deal as a sailor & who told some interesting facts about the Turks. They have only one meal a day it seems, consisting of some black bread made from ground Dura (a grain) &

a bowl of soup. They never give them any other regular rations & so they take these from the natives. This dura our people only use for feeding to the camels. It seems that the Turks were so short of fodder that they had to withdraw their cavalry from down Gaza way & send them up near Jerusalem.

When they started to retreat from Gaza the German officers attached kept all the motor cars for them selves & the trains for their staff & belongings etc. The Turks got angry at this & at several places pelted them with stone & even fired on the Germans.

Only for the Germans among them & the Austrians on the guns they would surrender in hundreds. Tis these Germans & Austrians too who make them put up as much resistance as they do.The German General in command out here could not get on with the Turks & went back to Germany.

On the
Entry.139:
day in our new position my mate went down with fever which I also contacted a couple of days later.

On the
Entry.140:
day down my mate got up & went to a Hospital in the village, where they kept him for a few days & then sent him down to Jaffa. They did nothing at all for us in the battery, & did not even get a doctor down.

I got up on the
Entry.141:
day but was very weak. Every week after this for about 6 weeks I would go down for a couple of days & when I got up again would be as weak as a chicken.

The doctors don't know exactly what the disease is but I reckon it was caused by the bites from the bugs. Since then men have alwaysbeen prohibited from sleeping in caves as that iswhere the disease originates.

I have not seen a sickness that weakens one so quickly. I must have dropped over 2 stone in weight through it.

Have seen a few air scraps here lately in all of which our machines came out winners.

The enemy shelled the village one day causing about 40 casualties, most of which were civilians.

For the remainder of that day there was a long string of cilvilians with their goods & chattel making for Jaffa.
Entry.142: Was reading in an Australasian an account of tthe mosaic work that used to be at Shellal & which is now in Australia.
Entry.143:
Tis becoming a regular thing now to have places up near the line where the troops get their blankets & clothes disinfected regularly & where they can have a hot disinfectant bath every 10 days or so. There is one in Mulebis that we go to.

The object of it is to keep down lice which are very plentiful in winter & which are supposed to cause cholera. As cholera is fairly rife up this way we have to be inoculated against it every 3 months.
Entry.144:
The almond trees are in bloom now making a very pretty sight indeed & what a few weeks ago was a big area of seemingly dead trees is now a mass of white. There is hanrdly a piece of bare ground about now.

All the almond & orange orchards have just been ploughed giving theground a very fresh appearance. One cannot help noticing that the fruit trees are remarkably free from diseases. The oranges also never had any scale on them.

The ploughs they use up this way are the small type of orchard plough we use at home, but differ in this respect that they have only a single handle, which makes them very easy to handle. The soil is a sandy loam & is very easy to work.

The rainy season is drawing to a close now & ought to be all over in a month or so. All the rain comes from the S. West & comes up very rapidly. I have seen the sky without a cloud visible & then it be raining inside a quarter of an hour.

Our Air Service has undergone a remarkable change during the last 3 months & we are absolutely superior in the air.

Our Nieuports & SE 5's get all over the Huns & average at least one a day at times for some considerable time. We have quite a lot of anti air craft guns here also which give the Huns a very hot time & their barrage stops them every time.
Entry.145: Moved up to a position in front of the village, only 1,500 yds behind the line. There is a battery of 18 pounders alongside us & on the other side
Entry.146:
Heavies also 60 pdrs. All these guns are on a 200 yds frontage.The field battery is going up closer for the stunt.

The enemy shelled us at 4 am on the morning we pulled in & tis likely to be a hot shop.

They have given us a dugout for the Huns, the first we have had. It is 6' x 6' x 6' with corrugated iron & 3 tons of earth on top.

Was relieved the next afternoon to go on leave. Stayed at the 113 Sqdn aerodrome that night at Sarona only a couple of miles out of Jaffa, as we had to bring in another chap next day from a battery over near the coast.

Next morning set out about 7 oclock for the battery & on the way out watched our barrage being put on a big hill they wanted to take. This is called Medjel Yaba .

We got into the aerodrome about 30 miles down the line, at 4 pm, having done the last 16 miles with a broken spring (we were in a Ford car).

Next day heard at the 'Drome that the stunt had been very successful - 400 prisoners taken. Some machine guns & an advance of 3 miles on 11 mile frontage.

We buried 400 Turkish dead & yet only sustained about 2 casualties ourselves, due to the artillery fire which was very heavy.

I expect to be in here for some days before going on leave as there are 2 away at present.
Entry.147:
Left Medjel Stn (near the drome) on night train arriving at Kantara next morning. Slept in open truck but had a fair amount of room.



Went on to Port Said by midday train as I wanted to see Dr Wood at the
Entry.148:
A.G.H. When I arrived there I found that he had not been to the hospital at all.

Had a look round the harbour at the shipping etc, went on board a French torpedo boat & had a look round. They are exceedingly small things of about only 100 tons & I would not like to go to sea in one for anything.

Almost all the ships were painted with broad stripes along the sides which rendered them almost invisible a a few miles distance.

We had a sail for a while in a small yacht & went out to visit De Lesseps Statue. Saw several of our submarine chasers in harbour. They are very fast motor boats mounting a small quick firer in front. They only have a crew of 2 officers & 6 men.

Port Said is a very dirty, dusty, uninteresting place with practically nothing to see excepting the shipping. Went to Cairo by the evening express 6.30 & got there at 11 pm.

The trams in Port Said are very much behind the time. They consist of only an old fashioned tram on rails drawn by 2 very insignificant donkeys.

Stayed the night at the New Khedival hotel & next afternoon went on to Alexandria by the 4.15 express. Arrived at Alex at 8 pm & stayed at the Windsor Hotel. It is the only English hotel in Alex is very nice & comfortable & costs 10/- per day. They are not allowed to charge soldiers more than 10/- per day by order of the Military Authorities & it is quite enough too.
Entry.149:
Went out shopping today as I had quite a lot of things to get. Shopping done properly would take a considerable time. To get an article at anything like its proper value you would have to go to 2 or 3 shops & find which is the lowest in price. They all have their own prices forsimilar articles.

One of the chaps wanted a certain kind of mirror &

priced it at 3 shops. One charged 12 PT for it another 14 & the third 20PT & yet the mirror was exactly the same in all cases.

The same thing applied we found to many other things. They often have special prices for Australians too as they say we have more money. This is not really correct as we cannot draw more than 3/- per day (L Horse 2/-) but when our chaps do have any money they throw it about more than the Tommies.

Went round the Harbour in a sailing boat one morning & took snaps of various things. Saw a big tramp with a huge hole in her side where a torpedo had hit her but in spite of this she had managed to get into port. Saw another steamer from which some one had removed the sea valves causing her to settle down. She had been down 6 weeks when I saw her but efforts were then being made to raise her.

Went round some of the oldforts that had been sadly knocked about in

the bombardment of 1881. The walls of themwere very solidly made & were as much as 7' thick in places but they would last no time against modern H.E. shells.

Went to the skating rink one afternoon. It was the first time that I had ever been on skates & in the first 5 minutes or so, I had about 12 busters. I began to improve however after a while.
Entry.150:
Went out to see the Catacombs this morning. These have only been excavated for the past 18 years. The lower catacombs were flooded from soakage from a lake near by.

Went out to Nouza gardens the same afternoon with my mate & 2 Aus Sisters who were down in Alex on leave. They were very nice indeed & it was a pleasure to meet & talk to some Australians girls again. One of them was engaged to a young Officer who used to be in our Regiment & has 3 brothers in it.

I was one of these the Major who recommended me for the M.M.

Spent a really enjoyable day with them & after tea took them for a long motor ride.
Entry.151:
Went to church this morning to St Catherines Cathedral. It was Palm Sunday & the church was fearfully crowded. I went away & came back an hour later & found it nearly as bad then. Went to Benediction the same evening.Today was the first service I had been to since last August before I left the regiment.

We went to the Museum this afternoon but did not think a great deal of it. It is not nearly as big nor as interesting as Cairo Museum.

Left Alex on 8.15am train on
Entry.154:
class carriage as soon as the train left the station. At Ben Ha we detrained & 5 minutes later caught another train going from Cairo to Port Said.

Saw the 2 nurses we had met at Alex in a 1st class car & they invited us in. We got in & were not pulled up during the whole of the

journey. Also had dinner on board the train in the Dining Car it costing us
Entry.155:
each.

Reached Kantara at 3 pm & at 6 left on the leave train across th desert. It consisted of open trucks with a rough boarded roof to break the power of the sun. We were packed in like sardines, 35 men per truck with hardly room to move & not much chance of sleeping.

Arrived back at Medjel next morning at 8 am. I had a great time during the week I was away living well & eating well but the journey back knocks all the benefit out of one.
Entry.156: Saw MickyTuson & Bob Stinson last night as they camped near the aerodrome for the night en route for the front again, after some months "spell" or so called down at Gaza.
Entry.157:
Had a fly this morning. Went up in a British Fighter & was only up a quarter of an hour when we had to come down owing to engine trouble.

Went up again in about 5 minutes time. We went up to about 8,000' & then the pilot signalled that he was going to do a stunt with me. Accordingly I gripped the rope inside the cockpit & the next thing I knew was that my heart seemed to come up into my mouth & we were falling at an awful rate, the machine twisting round & round.

I learned afterwards from the pilot that we had done a spinning nose dive for 3,500'. When we came out of the dive I was violently sick for about 5 minutes & had no interest in anything for the remainder of the flight. I felt weak & giddy on landing but a good dinner fixed me up.
Entry.158:
Left this morning to rejoin the battery which we found was still at Mulebis but was to move the following night for Medjel Yaba about 13 miles by road which we had only taken the day I went in on leave.

Our position is at the foot of Medjel Yaba which is a village set

naked on a big hill.
Entry.159: Saw an air scrap just in front of Medjel today, when 2 Huns & 1 of our Nieuport Scouts came down.
Entry.160:
There was to have been a big stunt here today but it was put off at the last moment for some reason or other.

Johnny has any amount of guns here now & nearly every morning wakes us up with an early morning drum fire.

The start of things in France may have something to do with the suspension of operations.
Entry.161:
Tis rumoured that Johnny is to attack tomorrow to try & retake Jaffa. Everyone seems to have the wind up completely, why I don't know & our guns have been withdrawn to a position 2,000 yds in rear of Medjel on account of this.

We are just on the edge of the hills here & the hills are covered with stones of all sizes. To our left is a valley which runs down to Ludd. This is about 4 miles wide, is very



level & it is through here that Johnny was expected to go as we had no guns & very few infantry on it. All the guns from both sides of the plain however were trained & the gunners stood to all night & at the waggon lines the horses were ready harnessed up all night.

The Field hospital behind us moved back 3 miles & the Group went back the same distance.
Entry.162:
Moved over to a position N of Mulebis & about 4 miles from it. We are beyond the Ajua River & only½ a mile beyond thefront line. We have a good natural cover however as we have our bivvy pitched in a wadi & the guns are on the bank of it.

We expect to get shelled here anyday as we have not got much cover in front of the guns to hide the smoke.

We travelled at night as usual & did not get into position until just before daylight. As usual we got stuck but managed to get out of it some how.

The country here is quite different from Medjel Yaba. Instead of rough rocky hills we have undulating sandy country covered with an abundance of grass & weeds.
Entry.163:
A Hun came over low this morning & set fire to two balloons suspended a mile or so in our rear. The occupants jumped out & landed safely by means of their parachutes.

As he dived at the balloons the Hun fired tracer bullets (incendiary) which caused the balloons to burst out into flames a couple of miniutes later. They were entirely burnt out before reaching the ground & all that was left of them was a big trail of black smoke in the sky.

Our anti aircraft guns opened on the Hun but their shooting was most erratic. Tis usual to pull the balloon down on the approach of Huns but they must have been caught napping this time as no attempt

was made to get them down. Another balloon went up next day but was pulled a couple of days later & has not since gone up.

The reason is that we have not got enough antis here to protect them as some were sent over to the Jordan where the huns have been very busy against our L. Horse lately.
Entry.164:
We were shelled today by a12cm gun. The 3rd shot was a direct hit on 1 gun & split the buffers apart. It could not have been a neater hit. 8 shells came over all together & all of them were very near the gun.The Sergt-Mjr was wounded. The gun crew was off the gun at the time or else theywould have all been wiped out.

Next night we moved to a position about½ a mile away to our left rear & the battery whose place we took went into our position. They have been frightened to fire since going in there. (Our gun had to go

(We are only 3 miles from the sea here) away the same night as it was knocked out & a week or so later we got one from our other section which has got a new gun.

16th

We were shelled here today shrapnel & H.E. No damage done but some of the shells burst among the mens bivouacs & one went 25 ydfrom the gun.

May 20th

There have been a lot of changes on this front during the past 6 weeks. The 52nd,
Entry.165: 74th & Yeomen Divns have gone to France while the
Entry.167:
Indian Divns have taken their place. There are still more Indians coming up the line & down below there are also a couple of Divisions of Indian Cavalry.

The Indians are not much chop, the Ghurkas being easily the best of them. To every 3 battalions of Indians they put 1 of white troops & the Indians oftenclear out & leave the whites in the lurch. The Indians are good in attack but

cannot stand heavy shelling. Tis rumoured that this front is to be held by Colonial troops & that the Australian Troops are coming back here & relieving all the English troops here. I wish it were true but one cannot believe all one hears.

Tis remarkable however how many of these rumours do come true. For instance we heard sometime ago that the Indians were coming here & were going to relieve the English Divns.

Never get any news now as we are forbidden to take any enemy or Allied press on the wireless & no news is sent out here by our own people. We take the German press sent out by Vienna at 10 pm & get it translated by a corporal in the battery who speaks German & French fluently.

We never post it up as it would put our show away. Tis the only way we can ever learn anything that is going on on 
this
 front even except in our immediate locality.
Entry.168: The River Auja has been put in bounds now for swimming & so we go down whenever we get the chance. As we cannot go together because one must always be at the stn during the day, we have an afternoon off in turn. The river is only half an hours walk from here. The river is a narrow swift running stream, almost too strong to swim against & not very deep, except in places. It is quite a treat to be able to get a decent swim.
Entry.169:
Have since learned that the Auja River has its source in some underground springs & an underground river which emerges at an old castle about 3 miles away. This accounts for it running so fast.

For the last couple of weeks there has been a plague of locusts here (Eastern plague locust) there being thousands of them & as a result of their ravages the herbage is dying off. They are about 1¼" long - 2", some having very short wings others having

full size wings, which are transparent & of a pinkish colour. When disturbed they rise & fly about 7 or 8 yards, very rarely going more than about 10 yds at one time. They have immense jaws & their hind legsare very well developed for jumping purposes. They are coloured like sand.

In the war news we have been receiving from Vienna during the last few days the Germans claim capture of Soissons & many other towns, 45,000 prisoners, 400 odd guns, thousands of machine guns & tremendous quantities of war material. Also the outer forts of Rheims have been taken & the city is almost surrounded. Am expecting anyday to hear of the capture or the capitulation of Rheims. They claim to have pushed the French back about 15 miles.
Entry.170:
During the last week or so we have been catching fish down in the Auja River, my mate caught a dozen one morning averaging abour a pound. A couple of

mornings later I caught 6 including a big cat fish or mud fish weighing about 4 lbs. The fish are either carp or perch we are not sure which. Personally I think they must be carp. For bait we use locusts & fish with a rod & float. The river teems with fish.

Between fishing & swimming one can get some sport & diversion from the monotony of the work here. We go down every day now one spending the morning & the other the afternoon & next day vice-verse & so on.

There have been a couple of stunts on here during the last 10 days there object being to lessen somewhat the great area of no mans land excisting at present (about 3,000 yds) & to deprive the enemy of some of his best observation posts.
Entry.171:
far all objectives have been attained with comparatively slight losses, & consolidated against all counter attacks. The enemy did not like losing some of these points & in one case counter attacked 7 times.

Prisoners amount to about 200 for both stunts but his losses due to

our artillery fire in first stunt were very heavy amounting to at least 1,000.

June 23rd

Yesterday afternoon went to see the
Entry.172:
Divn monthly race meeting. Managed to get a horse from the groom of the adjutant of 261 Bde RFA (Jocks) & so rode over to the course about 3 miles over.

The races were very successful & well managed. The horses were nothing very extraordinary, there being only a few real good ones. There were 7 races in all there being plenty of entries & as many as a dozen or more starters in some races.

There were no bookies present, the totalisator being in vogue here. Considering the circumstances it was fairly successful. There was not a great deal of money about & as the favourites came in in most cases the dividends were not very high.

S Wootton was riding but had a day off today. He has been very successful however at recent meetings. I did a little betting losing£1 on the day.

The distances mostly were short & the weight very high - catch weight over 10 & 11 stone. The main race - Jaffa Cup was a distance of 2 miles.

About 6 pm a Hun came over to have a go at the balloon just behind us. Our anties put up a very heavy barrage round it but he was determined to get it & made 3 attacks on the balloon, the last being successful.

I never expected him to come out of the barrage again as shells were bursting all round & over him & his machine must have been riddled. Twas a miracle almost that he survived the barrage.
Entry.173: of our scouts came up as he attacked the balloon the
Entry.174:
time & one of them chased him home but could not catch him though he was gaining on him rapidly. The Hun flew very low & landed in a wadi a few miles inside his own lines the machine in all probability crashing. The pilot must have been wounded as the machine was wobbling a good deal going home.

The pilot was a very brave man & deserves all credit for his bravery but I don't think he will feel inclined to repeat the performance for some considerable time after the hot reception he received, our battery fired on the machine later on as one of our machines reported a large crowd round it.

What the result was we don't know as it was getting dark. Even if our shells did not get it, the machine must have been so badly damaged, especially as it crashed, as to be be no longer serviceable.

This act was in retaliation for a shoot by our battery during the afternoon withballoon observation on an enemy motor transport convoy - 5 lorries being smashed up by direct hits & others damaged - a really good bit of shooting.

Just before dusk an enemy machine was forced to land in our line due to engine trouble - over near the coast which somewhat sets off the preceeding event.

Another balloon went up within half an hour of the first one's destruction & has been up all day.

A few days ago one of our scouts went over the enemy 'drome looking for fight & 4 enemy machines came up after him. He shot down 2 of them in flames & the others not wishing to share the same fate cleared off.
Entry.175:
Went to Jaffa this morning - it being about 2 hours ride distant. I had my heavy winter clothing & was in a bath of perspiration practically all the time I was in there.

Was very disappointed in Jaffa as it did not come up to my expectations. The shops had a very poor supply of goods with very little variety. In fact it took me nearly 4 hours before I could get any fishing tackle. Went all round the town including the seafront of which I took several snaps.

There is really no harbour, ships having to lie out some distance, their cargoes being brought in in surf boats which come through a break in the reefwhich lies about

¼ of a mile from the shore. In rough weather ships would have to put out to sea I should think.

There are only a few decent buildings including the Town Hall & a couple of buildings now being used as hospitals. Visited a nice but small Catholic Church in the town the first church I have been in this side of the Suez Canal.

Quite a big part of the town is out of bounds to troops but I did not let that hinder me from seeing anything. A Light Railway runs from the landing place through some of the streets & thence on right up to the front here doing a good deal of useful work & saving a lot of motor convoys up this way.

Learnt from some men of the Camel Corps that that body has been disbanded & converted into a new Bde of L Horse & to be armed with swords in addition to their rifles & bayonets.
Entry.176:
We have been expecting a Turkish attack now for the last week or so but as yet it has not eventuated. They are expecting gas this time & have taken all precautions against it. We have even overhauled our gas masks in case they may be necessary.

A Hun came over some days ago for the Balloon but was driven off by the anties. He evidently hoped to get in unobserved as he had rings on his lower planes which is contrary to all principles of the Hague Convention & if he was brought down could be shot as a spy.

This act was futile as he could not conceal the fact his machine was much different in appearance to ours & his engine was more powerful or at least made a much greater noise than our Scouts.

Our people have been taking great care of the balloon lately & pull it down immediately

on the approach of Huns. Also in the evening when they bring it up close to the line there are two scouts doing a constant patrol around it.

They have become very keen lately as regards taking any enemy or allied press & promise all kinds of severe punishment to any offenders caught. We have had several officers around lately & so we have decided to lay low for a time & have put our coil away out of sight. We were told to destroy it but cannot see our way clear to do that.

Anyhow tis not worth while risking a court martial just for sake of getting a little enemy press.

July 25th

About a week or so ago the German division attacked over near the Jordan. They were heavily replused & we took 350 of them prisoners also 150 Turks. This will mean a very serious blow to their prestige among the Turks.

Jaffa was shelled some days ago by an enemy submarine

which fired 6 rounds into the town with what result I don't know. They have also been shelling Ludd lately at a range of between 12 & 15 miles. Don't know the calibre of the gun.
Entry.177:
Several nights ago we had an all night bombardment of Johnny's roads & back areas as they were expecting him to withdraw from his present position which has been made almost untenable by our artillery concentrating on his roads & interfereing very seriously with his transport.

We have splendid observation on his roads etc & every convoy that goes along is shelled. Our battery alone fires practically all day on transport, motor lorries, infantry etc, going along behind his line.

Tis expected that the Germans are to be withdrawn from this front also a lot of the Turkish artillery which is manned by Austrian & German

gunners. If this happens it will leave him seriously weakened on this front.

Great preparations are going on now behind our line for the next big advance which is expected to come off next month. Two fine metal roads have been built practically up to the front line, one right on the coast the other a few miles inland.The Light railway has been pushed up to within a mile or so of the line.

There are great masses of cavalry down near Jaffa, all waiting for the push.The Brigade of Aus Cav is formed now & are training to use swords. There must be easily 30,000 cavalry from France & Meso, Yeomanry & L Horse.

Have been doing a lot of fishing lately & have been averaging about 10 a day for last week or so. We are the only two in the battery who seems to be

able to get any decent results though quite a lot of them try it.

Have been getting great news during past few weeks from France & this morning heard that we had taken another 17,000 prisoners & 300 guns with great quantities of war material.

Received some mail a few days ago dated
Entry.178: Last mail I had prior to this was of
Entry.180:
We have 2 Handley Pge machines out here now. They flew from England to Egypt their actual time in the air being 36 hrs. One of them is to be sent to our Sqdn.

Some mornings ago we had 7 huns over here. Two machines from our sqdn met them & brought down 4.

On
Entry.181:
of thismonth 2 of our machines tackled 4 up near Haifa bagging 2 of them.

Sent a cable on the
Entry.182: to Dr - for£10 to go on leave.
Entry.183:
One of our machines brought down 2 Huns one day last week. A Hun machine has had 2 attempts during

the past week to get the balloon but without success. The machine comes over with things on its wings looking like one of our machines.
Entry.184:
Our battery which has been separated (2 Sections) since Xmas joined up last night & we are staying with them.

There is a huge concentration of artillery going on along this Sector of the front. On a short front of about 7 or 8 miles we will have about 4 Bdes of Heavier (20 Batteries (4 guns each) & about 180 field guns. (There were about 400 guns in all.)

Further to the right in the hills by Medjel Yaba are some French 75 batteries. There is a French Division somewhere over there - The Light Horse - Anzac Division (including my old Regt) lay some 4 or 5 miles in rear of us.

The position we are in at present is a very open & exposed one & we are not to fire until the stunt starts. A heavy battery was shelled out of here about 5 months ago - being under direct observation from our right flank.

We are using a lot of new ideas out

here this time as motor machine gun batteries, aerial torpedoes etc & our flying machines are to machine gunning of troops & transport on an extensive scale having guns fitted for that purpose.
Entry.185:
For past few days our fighting machines have been doing an all day patrol for Huns & guarding the Balloons. Tis our usual procedure to sweep the skies of huns before a stunt starts.

While up the river fishing yesterday I saw a fine big beaver - the first I have ever seen alive either in captivity ot in its natural state. Did not have any firearms with me so could not shoot it though I would like to obtain the skin of one.

There are a fair number in the river but this is the first one I have seen. It came to the surface only a couple of yards from where I was sitting & remained on top for about½ a minute. There are any amount of tortoises in the river varying in size from 3" to 2' across.

the back. Crabs also are very numerous along the banks of the river & I have seen them as much as 8" long.
Entry.186:
Winter Campaign starts.

At 0400 this morning we started on the winter campaign. There was an intense bombardment from about 400 guns at least lasting an hour & lifting at various intervals. The first objectives were quickly gained & prisoners came over in hundreds.Have not yet any idea as to our haul of prisoners & guns but would be inclined to put it at about 2,000 prisoners & 40 guns.

Our aircraft played a great part in this day's work, especially in artillery cooperation which resulted in all hunbatteries being quickly silenced or put out of action.

Our bombing machines have been going backwards & forwards all day but not a hun machine have we seen, our air supremacy is absolutely over whelming.

Our position tonight is about 5 miles in front of the position we occupied this morning. We moved forward at about 11 am.



on our way to our present position (alongside Kafa Saba in a fig orchard) we passed a captured battery of 4:2" hows & in the same wood as we are in is a 4 gun battery of 77 mm guns. About¼ mile away is also a 5.9" How.

The ground all around the guns here is simply pockmarked with shell holes - the result of this mornings work. Our artillery fire today was overwhelming & played tremendous havoc among Johnnies positions.Infantry men I have met say our Barrage this morning was absolutely the best they have ever experienced.

We are on very short rations of water for first few days only 2 bottles the first 4 days equal to a pint a day. Tis so hot trudging along that one could easily drink a gallon.

My mate & myself caught two turkish ponies this afternoon & are going to ride them during the advance, mine is a small Bay Turkish stallion & very sturdy.Tonight went over to Kafa Saba where we watered our ponies, had a good wash & refilled our bottles.
Entry.187:
far today we have captured Jiljulia , Kalkilih , Kafa Kasam, Kafa Saba, Bir adas & are getting well up into the hills. The L Horse are pushing up

the coast & we hope in a few days to have the whole Turkish army surrounded in the Mts.
Entry.188:
Had hardly got into bed last night when we had to pack up again & go on another 6 or 7 miles as the enemy was retreating so fast as to get out of range. On the way passed through Kalkilieh, a fair sized village & the Turkish railhead.

Went into position just near a place called Hableh & alongside our position are 3 enemy field guns, the gunners of one of the guns having been bayoneted at their guns.We are in the hills now & tis very rocky &uneven.

The enemy seems to have retreated so fast during the day (yesterday) that they don't know exactly where he is.

Did not get a wink of sleep last night as we did not get into this position until just before daybreak. One big advantage about travelling at night now is that the moon is almost full. We did not fire a shot all day as we were probably out of range when we got here.

Just heard that our L. Horse at 10 am this morning were 10 miles from Haifa & that yesterday this Corps alone -
Entry.189:
- took 5,000 prisoners & 70 guns.

We are at least 20 miles behind the front line now & expect to get a full nights sleep tonight.

Our aeroplanes have been passing to & fro all day long in fours & fives, on Bombing Raids & still we have not seen a Hun machine. Our air service had gone a long way towards the success of the stunt.

We are not meeting with the water difficulties which they prepared for & its just as well pleased we are too that such is not the case.
Entry.190:
Have not left Habelieh yet & are not likely to do so for some days as we are hopelessly out of the pursuit. The infantry have been having a pretty rough time owing to lack of water, as it cannot be got up to them as quick as they advance & there is not much where they are now.

Anzac Divn took Nazareth at 6 am this morning & Haifa is expected to fall at any time. Some German troops (Jagers) are fighting vey stubbornly here now, but all the Turk thinks of is flight.

Every gun the Turks had - 71 - between Hableh & the sea on his first defensive system were taken which shows how swift was our first blow & they must have been surprised as in any amount of places we visited the occupants, has been disturbed in bed.

While here we are going to see as much of the surrounding country on our ponies as possible.

Tis 2 yrs today since I landed in Egypt.
Entry.191:
Left Hableh this morning & went back to Kafa Saba to be nearer the water supplies. Stayed here 3 days during which time we traversed the country side for miles around on our ponies.

Saw a lot of Turkish guns & at Kalkili there are 20 5.9" Hows alone. Saw 4 guns - old pattern German Cannon mad in 1872, 3, 4,5 yrs respectfully, calibre 12 cm. Twas one of these that knocked our gun out last May. They are practically obsolete & resemble the old guns on the forts at Alexandria.
Entry.192:
Moved up to Tul Keram this morning - 10 miles beyond Kalkili . This is a fair sized railway junction & boast a native & a Jewish village. On the road up we passed about 3,000 Turks & Germans going down the line.

Had some heavy rain today & we got a proper soaking.

The total number of prisoners now is 60,000 & the L. Horse are reported to be a few miles from Damascus.

We expect to be moving on again to Haifa in a day or so.

Some German prisoners whom we have questioned say that the Turks let them down here & laughed at us for saying we took Metz. The last German news they had had was that they were only a few miles from Paris.

The prisoners are a very ragged lot indeed a great number not having any boots ever & in nearly all cases their clothes consist of patchwork of all kinds & colours of material.

Their physique is better than any previous lots we have captured.
Entry.193:
We were to have started on a 4 days trek to Haifa today but the move was cancelled late last night.

Twas read out on a general parade today that Bulgaria had surrended & handed over her railways etc. The news was taken very quietly, almost as a matter of course.

Tis unofficially said that Turkey has surrended also. Though not confirmed yet, I think it only a matter of a few days before Turkey gives in asher position is rendered much more critical by the caving in of Bugaria.

General Allenby a few days ago entered Damascus in state & Beirut is expected to fall at any time now.

There are 50 guns parked down at Tul Keram Station & this with the 70 we saw at Kalkili makes 120 on this coastal sector.
Entry.194:
of them 5.9" Hows which is a much higher number than we thought he had as he never used more than two or three on our sector, though he had any amount of them. Some of them are brand new - made at Krupps in 1917.

The flies are awfully bad up here - a hundred times worse than they used to be behind our own lines & we used to think them bad enough then.In some German & Turkish camps I have visited, in parts you could hardly see the ground for flies.

Fleas also are very numerous & you have only to step inside a native house & you yet covered with them.

On our way home from Kalkili , we stopped for shelter from the rain at an old Turkish telephone exchange & in a few minutes got covered with fleas. Since coming here we have been kept awake long hours at night by them.

Yesterday we sprinkled all our blankets & clothes with creosol, which effectively got rid of them.

Wentthrough the town of Tul Keram yesterday but found it much the same as all such native places. Tis not quite as big as Ramleh.

Met some Christian Arabs in

the town. They speak fair English & said they were very glad indeed to be freed from the Turkish oppression.

Up to the
Entry.195: the official number of prisoners was 50,000 & the guns 360. At the time of our offensive starting the Turkish forces here were about 100,000 strong & consisted of the
Entry.196:
7th & 8th Armies. The 7th & 8th armies were absolutely annihalted while the remnants of the 4th army escaped across the Jordan into the barren regions beyond where they got a bad mauling from Arab regulars & natives who rose against them & tis doubtful if any of them will get clear evetually.

We have possession now of a large portion of the Hedjaz running from Damacus south which effectively cut off any Turkish forces in the Hedjaz .

We are all wondering now what will happen to the troops here in the event of Turkey giving in. The general concensus of opinion is that the greater part of the forces here will go to Italy or to the Balkans.
Entry.197:
Received orders unexpectedly last night to proceed to Haifa (4 days trek) & left this morning at 0900. Travelled slowly during the day as the horses are weak on account of being on½ rations & camped at 4.30 pm near an excellent water supply, having come about 13 miles.

Todays journey brings us near the end of the plain of Sharon & tomorrow we will be in the hills again. During the whole day we passed through cultivated land which had only quite recently harvested. The crop is not unlike sorghum in many respects & though I am not certain I think it is a grain called "Doura".

Had a heavy shower of rain this morning shortly before leaving. The ponies are in great fettle & are picking up wonderfully.
Entry.198:
Reveille was at 03.00 am this morning & we were on the road before 4.30, it being still dark. After the first 4 miles we halted for an hour or so at the foot of the hills. It was a very steep pull for a mile or so & it took about 2 hours to get all the guns & waggons etc up.

At the top of the hill is the Jewish village of Zimmeran . From here one can get a fine view of the surrounding country overlooking the Plain of Sharon for miles & miles to the south, on the west of the sea being only a couple of miles away.

We are camped at the foot of the Hills just beyond the village but still in the Pass. The country around here is very nice indeed there being any amount of olive orchards about & mimosa hedges along the road sides are out in bloom.
Entry.199:
Yesterday we left Zimmeran at 4 am travelled about 10 miles & camped at a place called Atlit on the beach. From here the road runs within a couple ofhundred yards of the sea all the way to Haifa.

Atlit is only represented by the ruins of an ancient palace which has evidently been a beautiful place in its time. The buildings covers an area of about 2 acres & some parts are in a fair state of preservation, one part in particular is a section of a wall standing about 50' high, about



9' thickness & composed of big blocks of stone about 4' x 2' x 2'. The ruins stand on a point of land & on either side is a small bay.This must have been a jolly fine place at one time.

Had two good swims yesterday & enjoyed it immensley. Also gave our ponies a swim. This is the first occassion this year that I have been in the sea.

Today we left again at 4 am & only travelled 5 miles & then camped. We are only 2 miles from Haifa but cannot go through in daylight on account of the congestion of traffic.We are leaving at about 3 am tomorrow as we must be through it by 5 am.

I think the real reason however is that they want us to go through unseeen by the inhabitants. Already a lot of spies have been caught in Haifa.

Our horses are in pretty bad condition as they are only on½ rations or less. We have only lost 3 or 4 so far however which is good considering the conditions under which we have been walking.

By starting off at 4 am we can get most of the days journey done ere the sun gets very strong.
Entry.200: far we are the only heavy horse battery that has come over the pass at Zummeran.
Entry.201:
Came to Haifa last night. Our guns are on coast defence just on the northern outskirts of the town until the proper 4.7" coast defence guns come up.

Just across the road from us & at the foot of Mt Carmel is our aerodrome which is extremely convenient for us. On the point of Mt Carmel range which ends fairly abruptly only a couple of hundred yards from the sea is a lighthouse, which is now being used by our O.P. as a lookout for submarines.

The hill towersover the 'drome & is fairly steep. Running along the slope to the top is a made up road which has a fairly steep gradient. It takes about an hour to go to the top, walking.Near the Lighthouse is a monastery (German one) but the occupants are gone now.

The Bay of Haifa is a fairly deep one & Acre can be seen very distinctly across on the farther shore. Ships can lay in very close to the shore, but there is only one small stone pier for a landing place.

This morning there was a big hospital ship in which sailed with a full cargo during the day.

On top of the hill are 2 German Krupp 15 cm (6") coast defence guns (1898 pattern) which are manned by our gunners now.

The town looks well from a distance with its white houses & red tiled roofs rising on the hill side & boasts two or three fine big buildings.

Today
Entry.202:
ascended Mt Carmel to see the Lighthouse & Monastery of Elijah which we were not allowed inside as there is a guard on it in the absence of the monks. A splendid view is obtained from the Lighthouse of the town, the Bay of Acre, & the town of Acre in the distance.

Also went out to see the 5.9" coast defence Krupp guns about 2 miles along the top of the mountains, only one is in working order, the other being in course of erection. The gun weighs about 25 tons & has a range of 17,000 metres. It is also absolutely intact except for the dial sight which the Germans no doubt took away with them.It fires armour piercing shells.

Today
Entry.203:
went through Haifa on way to River Makupta, 2 miles beyond the town. We tried to do some fishing

but without success as it was too shallow near the banks & we did not have much time in which to explore it. Tomorrow afternoon we are going to spend in the town.
Entry.204:
Spent the afternoon of yesterday in town but was disappointed with it. The lower part of the town near the water front & railway yards is very dirty & much the same as any other native place. The streets are narrow & when traffic goes through it has to go through one street & back by another as there is no room to pass.

The shops at present contain very little & in the markets one can obtain plenty of tomatoes fairly cheap, dried figs, pommegranits, water melons, eggs at 3 for 1/- & native bread. Everything is very dear, prices for the Military being much higher than for the civilian population.

The European or German & Jewish quarter is in higher ground at the rear of the town & is very nice & clean with plenty of trees about - almond & olive & the streets of this quarter are all planted with trees.



There are 2 or 3 fair sized hotels & now being used as HQ's by the military. Some fine big buildings are now being used as Hospitals for our & Turkish & German wounded.

The waterfront presents a very busy scene as yesterday 5 cargo steamers came in & are landing large quantities of supplies by means of lighters.

A big Hospital ship came in yesterday, filled up during the day & sailed this morning just after daybreak having emptied the clearing stations here. The sick & wounded were taken out on big lighters to the ship which was anchored out about a¼ of a mile.

There are any amount of religious institutions in the town & this morning I went to mass 0615 at a German Convent.

The bay is an excellent swimming place & one can go out as far as desired in quiet water.
Entry.205:
This morning I spent in looking over the Carmelite Monastery of Elijah on the point of the mount. This is a fine building & contains some dozens of rooms. Prior to our occupation it was used as a German HQ's, the monks



having been twice ejected. Before departing the Germans looted the whole place & many of the rooms were turned upside down & the contents scattered all over the floor.

The chapel is a very fine place indeed, the high altar being better than anything I have yet seen. At the top of the altar & slightly in rear is a statue of our Lady with 2 angels kneeling at her feet, one on either side. Immediately in rear of the altar is a big room used as a Choir Room & the whole statue of the Virgin & the angels could be turned by some mechanical means to completely round, to face this.

Below the altar & in the solid rock is a receptacle cut out, & which contains the bones of all deceased monks for some considerable time past. It seems that when a monk dies he is buried in a near by cemetry & a few years later his bones are disinterred & placed in this receptacle below the altar.

They had a fine library at the monastry & this has not been interfered with very much. There are plenty of evidence of recent German occupation in the way of notices in German

posted up on walls, doors, etc all over the building. They must have been a working order I think, as in underground rooms we saw carpenters shops, paint shops etc, a spirit making place.

The monks cubicles were of a fair size & moderately well furnished with bed, table, chairs etc.

In front of the monastery is a statue of Our lady erected by the Chilian Govt.

The L House buildings were really the Palace of Abdulla Pacha though I don't think much of it as apalace, for an ordinary residence it wouldbe fine.

We are getting fresh meat & bread at last & tis a great relief to us. Half the Gun detachment are in hospital now & everyone else is very weak. I have not been at all well lately & put it down to the grub we are getting.

Our broad gauge railway is up as far as Tul Keram now which ought to ensure a plentiful supply of fresh rations up here.
Entry.206: The weather has broken now, the last few days being very overcast & accompanied by strong winds. Have not had much rain however.
Entry.207:
The Handley Page Machine flew up here today from Ramleh. As she came over the mountain she looked just like a great bird floating along. She is a huge machine & to look at her you would not think she would rise off the ground.

She has 2, 360 HP Rolls Royce Engines, a crew of 5 & can carry a ton of bombs. She is sobig that one of our big hangars which ordinarily will hold 6 B. Fighters is not big enough for her. To get her in, her wings have to be folded back along the fuselage & even then it takes up the whole of the hangar.

She is very slow in the air only doing about 80 miles & seems to move very slowly. Though slow & clumsy in manouvering she is heavily armed & at times mounts as many as 8 or 10 machine guns, which would make her a very formidable opponent.

Today, she was to go on to our advanced aerodrome about 150 miles up with a load of about 60 odd tins of petrol & some oil. She is fitted with wireless both sending & receiving, the latter not having been used yet however.
Entry.208:
Today at 12 am an armistice with Turkey was to start. The news was taken very quietly here there being no demonstrations except tonight for a time when a lot of flares & fireworks were sent up. We came back into the 'drometoday having left the battery for good.

Tis rumoured that we are going to England (Wireless only) which accounts for our being withdrawn & I sincerely hope it turns out to be true but the war may be over
by Xmas
before we get to England.

Some of our chaps while out bombing fish this afternoon killed a shark about 7' long.
Entry.209:
Yesterday an armistice was signed with Austria.

Some of the mechanics here put a 20 HP Ford engine into a confiscated Turkish boat, with excellent results, attaining a speed of as much as 10 knots.

Went for a trip across the bay in her this morning towards Acre but was disappointed in not landing as we were limited for time. It was not very rough, just a swell but it made me sea sick - afterward however I was quite alright. There were 8 on board & the boat went exceedingly well.
Entry.210:
Left the aerodrome this morning on the initial stage of our journey to England. There are 26 all told - wireless operators - & 5 (1914) men going home to Australia.

We set off at 6.30 am in 2 motor lorries & reached Tul Keram at 10 am, after a very quick but rough & dusty 3½ hours travelling.

At Tul Keram had to sit down until about 2 pm before we knew that we could get a train down at all. We are travelling in usual way all jammed in an open truck with our kit. Can see no hope of getting any sleep tonight unless it is sitting up, as we are so packed in with kit etc.

Since we left here early last month this place has undergone a wonderful transformation. Our broad guage railway is some miles beyond here now, the old Turkish line between here & Haifa being used until our line gets through.

There is a great dump of Turkish guns, waggons, ammunition, etc here including about 40 odd 5.9" Howt.

Was not sorry to leave Haifa as the weather

during the past few days has been very windy & cold & also there has been a good deal of sickness in the Sqdn lately.

Got a train at 6 pm for Ludd & another one there at 0330 for Kantara. Ludd station is a huge place now being nearly as big in extent as Sydney station. The trip from Ludd down was a very dreary & monotonous one & we did not get into Kantara until 1750.

After travelling intermittintly since 6.30 am yesterday morning we travelled about 270 miles. Stayed at Kantara for the night & next morning early went into Moascat 25 miles further down the canal. At Moascat we went into "A". Details pending embarkation overseas.
Entry.211:
An armistice with Germany was signed yesterday, the news being received here without much demonstration or enthusiasum. We are very seriously afraid now that our trip to England will be cancelled owing to the armistice.

All the 1914 men are down here now awaiting embarkation any day for Australia.

This afternoon a party of about 20 returned prisoners from Turkey arrived here in camp. They have had a pretty rough time in captivity. Some being taken on the Peninsula & they look aged & was worn as a result of their treatment.

They said that they only had 2 meals a day - grain - & that only for parcels & money from home could not have existed even. They are very anxious to get home & will be sailing in a day or two with the '14 men.
Entry.212: The 1914 men & prisoners of war sailed today from Suez leaving here last night. There are about 1,000 in all.
Entry.213:
A lot of 1914 menwere given the option of furlough in England instead of going home immediately. A batch of 50 left here this morning to embark for England via Italy.

We are not going & I think we must have missed altogether now. Was on guard some days ago (24hours) at the Venercal compound. There are about

240 in it at present.

Moascar has not altered much & is just as quiet as ever. There are pictures every night & boxing once a week. There are a couple of good restaurants in the Camp now, one run by the camp authorities & any amount of canteens.

Tis still fairly warm here but I don't do much swimming as the lake is not very clean now. Tis rumoured that the Squadron is coming down to Heliopolis from Haifa.
Entry.214:
Went to Church this morning in Ismailia on the occasion of a thanksgiving service. This was the first time that I had been in the Church at Ismailia. Twas High Mass & among the congregation were a number of Marines off a French Cruiser laying in the Lake at present.

General Allenby went through this morning to Cairo to receive a public welcome. The whole camp here was lines up at the Station as his train steamed slowly through.

There has been quite a lot of speculation



lately regarding demobilisation & the method they will adopt. We are all firmly of the opinion here that they will get us out of Egypt as quickly as possible owing to the great amount of sickness among our troops.

Roughly there are only about 15,000 Australians here & as we will be taking no horses back it ought not to require many transports to take us home.

I heard that the
Entry.215:
Bde alone are shooting 700 horses at least 25%. This comprises all old horses & those worn out. The remainder will in a all probability be sold in Palistine or Egypt while some will be used for food.

Tis rumoured here that the Anzac Divn at present at Ludd will all be across the Canal by the
Entry.217:
the "Ceramic" will sail for Australia with a full compliment.

A lot of reinforcements came here yesterday - Nearly 700 & went into isolation. They had been on the water 8 weeks & looked very bad indeed. About 200 are in hospital & several deaths occured from meningitis.

They had some hundreds of horses on board & on the declaration of the armistice had to go back to Bombay & land them as they are of no use here now & once they came into Egypt they could not leave it again.
Entry.219:
for 48 hrs leave to get my money from the Bank. Had a very good time but regretted that the leave was not7 days instead of 2.

Caught a very heavy cold yesterday & can hardly speak today.

Had a big mail in some days ago & I got 14 letters by it.

We leave here tomorrow to rejoin the Sqdn at Ramleh. Am sorry to leave here as I was getting used to it. The grub could not be improved on & tis fairly warm & also we have done practically nothing since we came here.

One of the Handley Page machines left Cairo a couple of days ago to fly to Bombay via Damascus & Baghdad. This would be a very nice trip if one could manage to go on it.

As soon as I rejoin the Sqdn I am applying for leave to Jerusalem.
Entry.220: Arrived at Sqdn yesterday morning at Ramleh. We are the only remaining Sqdn up here now & I don't expect that we shall be here very long.
Entry.221:
It has been raining continuously now for 2 days & the camp is just like a quagmire. The camp is not pitched on high enough ground & consequently the water cannot get away quick enough. Everywhere one goes the mud is inches deep but fortunately it is not very sticky.

Some of the showers have been extremely heavy, once or twice accompanied by hailstones & I reckon we must have had at least 8" of rain up to the present. Tis so miserable here, nowhere to go & all we can do is lay in our tents all day & read or sleep.

Luckily our tent keeps the rain out very well but even so everything is so damp.

We were to have gone to Jerusalem yesterday, but the rain prevented it & it may be a week or more bre we can get up there.
Entry.222:
Some days ago several of us put in for 3 days leave to go to Jerusalem but were turned down.

Today however a party of 24 of us went up in a lorry.Left at 8 am arriving in Jerusalem about 10.30. The first 6 or 7 miles to Latronwas fairly level going but after passing Latron we began to climb & practically continued to do so all the way to Jerusalem.

At some places there were some careful manipulation. The road all the way was splendid & very free from dust owing to rain during the past few days. All the main roads of this country are splendid ones, much better than any we have in Australia, over such distance & under such conditions of rainfall etc.

These roads have to be built up in places & are just wide enough for 2 lorries to pass comfortably. The country we passed through was very bare & except for olive trees in places, there was no vegetation evident.

On nearing Jerusalem you cannot see it until you are right onto the City as it is hidden by a hill & as you go round it & turn the

bend you are in the city. We went straight through to Bethlehem about 6 miles south of the city as we would just have time to visit it & get back to the city for dinner.

At Bethlehem, which turned out to be bigger than I expected, the main thing of consequence is the Church of the Nativity, being as its name indicates, the birth place of Christ. The church has three parts, the Greek Othordox, Armenian & Catholic.We saw the manger & the place where the star leading the wise men stoppedover.

From near by we could see across the hills & the Jordan Valley, the Hills of Moab rising in the distance. Could not see into the valley however or the Dead Sea as they are down between the two lots of hills.

On the road out is a private residence of palatial dimensions which cost nearly£20,000 to build. Also on way out passed the Solomon's Pool at which Solomon was supposed to have been crowned King of Judea.

Returning to the City we dispersed for lunch arranging to meet at 2.30 near the Fast Hotel

to go & visit the Holy City.

On first entering the city we secured the services of a Cook's guide to show us round for the day. This chap, an Assyrian, speaks about 6 languages & knew his job well.

We went to the Carlton Restaurant for dinner & had a 3 course meal for 15 PTS (3/-), consisting of Soup, Meat Pie (a few chips of potatoes, carrots & beans with some mince between two small pieces of pastry) & for dessert 2 small cakes with a fairly decent cup of tea to end up.One would not pay 6dfor the same in Australia, but this was about as good a dinner as you could procure anywhere in the City.

After dinner we went for a stroll round the outer or New City till itwas time to go into the Old City. There was not much to see except that there were some very fine buildings in the City the size & appearance of which rather surprised me.

Did not have time to got out to the Mount of Olives or to the Garden of Gethsemeneh though I would very much like to have done so.

There are a fair number of shops, but

every second one sells curios etc of the Holy Land, supposed to be made here. Some of it is, but quiet a lot is made in Birmingham or in Germany.

The old City is entirely enclosed by a wall & has 2 main gates or entrances, the Jaffa Gate & the Damascus Gate. We went in by the Jaffa Gate & came out the same way not seeing the Damascus Gate at all.

There are guards on all the gates & soldiers are not allowed in or out except in parties and an officer or a YMCA guide while the civilians of all nations alike & creeds can go in or out at will.

At the Jaffa Gate is the town of David surmounted by a four faced clock. On entering the old City the first place of importance which we struck was the fine Lutheran church - which was opened by the Kaiser while on his visit here some years ago.Thence we went on through the Bazaar to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre.

The market quarter has very narrow streets entirely shut off from sunlight by the

buildings rising on either side which are shops & residences above these perhaps. There seems no lack of foodstuffs especially vegetables, (onions, cabbages, turnips, radishes, etc) oranges, in addition to the rice, nuts, figs, etc always more or less in evidence.

We went all through the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, which is beyond my powers of description. As at Bethlehem it was divided into its 3 parts Greek, Armenian & R Catholic.

We saw the Sepulchre, the place where the cross rested, the place where the Centurian watched the crucifixion from & was converted etc. A statue we saw was ornamented with about£150,000 worth of jewellry.

After leaving this church we went along the Via Dolorosa to the Church of "Ecce Homo", which is really a convent of the 

Here we saw part of the old Roman road through Jerusalem which has been preserved also some games of the Roman soldiers cut in the floor, one of the nuns there explained all

about it to us talking at the rate of about 19 to doz.

Over the Altar in the chapel is the inscription in Latin "Forgive them father for they know not what they do!" & which they have to say every day during Mass.

Leaving here we went on to the Mosque of Omar raised by the Caliph Omar in 7th Century & which is the
Entry.223:
centre of importance in the Mohamedan faith. Before going in we had to take off our boots as no one is allowed in wearing boots or shoes.

Inside this mosque is a big stone with a hole in the centre which is said by the Mohamedans to be the place where Mohammed ascended to Heaven. The rock was supposed to have tried to follow him in. The Hebrews believed that this was where the sacrifices used to be held, the hole in the rock being to drain the blood away.

Also there is a part of the rock supposed to have been the imprint of Mohammed's hand. Also a casket containing 3 hairs reputed to be hairs of Mohammed.The Rock is surrounded by a Lattice work screen.

The Dome of this mosque is a beautiful thing, wonderfully worked. Near by is the Mosque of El Aska, which was originally a Christian church raised about the
Entry.224:
century but which was taken over by the Mohammedans & converted into a mosque. On the walls are written the names of the Caliphs.

The next place we saw was the Wailing Place of the Jews which was not very well patronised this afternoon however, we could see the Garden of Gethsemeneh & the Mount of Olives just across the way but time did not admit us seeing them at close range.

A day is realy not enough in which to see Jerusalem thoroughly but as it is all we could obtain it is better than not seeing it at all.

I am very glad now that I have had a chance to see the Holy City both old & new & the places of such world wide interest, where Our Lord spent part of His life & where he died for us.

We left at 5 pm & got back to the drome about 7 pm.
Entry.225:
Some few days ago the L Horse over at Rischon had a set to with the inhabitants of a village. It appears that a couple of natives were caught thieving in the New Zealanders camp & shot a Sergt-Major who died a few hours later.

The N Z's sent next morning an ultimatum to the Shiekh of the village to hand over the murderer before sundown, to be dealt with. This was not complied with & at sundown about 1,200 men of 2 Anzac Divn surrounded the village & after sending away the women & children set to on the men, killing over 90 of them with rifles, pick handles, etc.The Horse Artillery (Scotties) attached to the Divn were in it also.

There is an inquiry on at present but I don't expect much will come of it. We did hear that the Divn was ordered back to the Jordan as a punishment & that they point blank refused to go but I can't vouch for the truth of this.

Yesterday three lorries went over from here to the Anzac Divn Races at Rischon about 8 miles away & I availed myself of the chance. We had a good afternoons sport, there being some splendid racing.

The best race of the day was the Steeplechase of about 2 miles which had a very large field. About 8 horses came down & several riders were injured. The race finally developed into a gruelling contest between two horses which kept together all the way until the last 100 yards or so when one sprinted in some lengths ahead of the other, which was done.

I backed the winner. I had 4 bets on the day & 3 of them were wins & 1 second, thus clearing£5.

I nearly missed the lorries coming home as I had to draw£3 on the last race & by the time I had drawn it, I had to run all the way to where the lorries had been left - about½ a mile & when I got there they had gone. I went along the road a few hundred yards & found one stuck so that I did not have to walk after all.
Entry.227: was a wet day so the sports were postponed until
Entry.228:
was fine however &today though overcast all day, has been fine. For past two days the men have been having a wild & woolly time indeed. Nearly the whole squadron was drunk yesterday & last night, as unlimited quantities of beer (Bass) & wine (Richon) were obtainable, beer at 9PT per bottle & wine 12PT.

We had our Xmas dinner at 6 pm & it was a fine one too, & the cook must have put in a lot of work to prepare such a blow out. His efforts did not go unappreciated however, as the mess thanked him & drank his health etc.

The menu consisted of Soup Tomato, Roast Meat with 3 vegetables, Plum Pudding, Jelly & Custard.

The Concert at night was very good but was somewhat marred by the objectionable remarks & behaviour of some of the men in the audience who were drunk. The Concert was very well got up & must have required a



lot of time for practice & for preparing the necessary paraphanalia. The second half of the programme consisted of a farce "Going home" the scene being the deck of the ship, with the actors in the guise of officers, nurses, men & ships complement. This was the best part of the concert.

The squadron orchestra were in attendance but were not up to their usual form, due no doubt to the dinner.Fortunately the Concert party were sober, or sufficiently so to do their parts properly.

There were a lot of officers present including the Brig Gen, the Major of Squadron & other officers.As is usual on these occasions several of the officers were "told off", peculiarities of characters speech etc being brought out. Also some including the CO & EO were called all kinds of nice names by some of the men & told off properly.

Of course the only course open to them was to take it all & say nothing. We expected the CO to be counted out when he came round to the Mess Huts at dinner time but this did not eventuate.

On the
Entry.229:
there was a big review by General Allenby at Cairo & taking part in the proceedings was a formation of 100 machines. One chap an expert pilot & instructor was killed owing to the collapse of his machine while stunting.

Our Squadron was not invited to participate in this affair as it was to be a show for the "Training Squadrons" ours being the only Squadron in the field now. 7 of our machines flew down to Cairo however as some of the officers wanted to see the celebrations. The flight - a non-stop one took just 3 hours the distance being about 300 miles.
Entry.230: We had the Squadron sportsmeeting this afternoon in fine weather & they were a great success. There were only 2 running events the 100 yds Sqdn Championship & a 120 yards open Championship. I won my heat in both events & came second in final 100 yards, being beaten by about 6". Time 11
Entry.231:
In final of 120 yds I came a dead heat with Tommie & so had to re-run it.

In the re run I beat the pistol & won by about 10 yds. The other chap entered a protest, which was upheld by the Committee & so we had to re run it again, although I would have been quite right in refusing as the other chap was quite in the wrong. However I won the
Entry.232:
