re run by about 3 yds in 14 secs. Thus I won£8.10 on the day£6 for 120 yds &£2.10 for the 100 yds.

In the 100 yds I ran in sandshoes & would no doubt have won if I had had the proper spiked shoes that I used in the 120 yards. I had a lot of running to do, twice in the 100 yds & 4 times in 120 yds & so am pretty tired tonight but joyful.

I think I was a surprise packet today but no one was more surprised than myself.
Entry.233:
We have had no rain during the past 10 days it being very fine & very warm until yesterday morning which turned out to be very cold. It started raining after dinner & has continued intermittently since.

The Squadron is expected

to be handing over any day now & proceeding to Kantara. Everything will be handed over including machines & we will only leave here with our own personal belongings.

We are supposed to be going to England & on account of this we have to do 1½ hours drill per day. The first morning this started we had to get up at 0545 am & so we counted them out & marched off parade.

A couple of mornings later the early morning parade hour was altered to 0645. We do½ an hour before breakfast & an hour during the morning. Needless to say we don't take much interest in the drill.

Started a Rugby Football team after the New Year & it is now on a good firm basis though at first the men were not very enthusiastic about it. We played GHO Signals last week being beaten by 6 - 5. This match aroused a good deal of interest in the game since

then we have had a lot more chaps turn out to practice. We have not got much combination or condition yet but as the men are very keen now we should soon have a fine team. I am secretary & skipper, & am quite satisfied as I reckon we have the makings of an excellent team.

Had intended going on 7 days leave to Damascus,Beyrout etc but now that the wet season has started properly I will have to postpone it, probably altogether.
Entry.234:
Yesterday 2 mates & myself left Ludd on the 0720 officers train for Haifa. It had rained slightly overnight & was very threatening. The line to Haifa is a broad gauge one now, running along the sea coast when past Zimmerin in some places being only about 20 yds from the waters edge.

At Haifa, where it was raining still, the line runs on an esplanade on water edge, right round Bay into Stn. Arrived Haifa at 1020 & immediately got into a train on the narrow gauge 3'6"

that was leaving for Damascus at 11. The carriages on the train, though the seats are hard, are very comfortable & travel very smoothly indeed - what a contrast to the way we have to travel going to Egypt in open cattle trucks, whereas coming up here we got a first class train.

Shortly after leaving Haifa & after skirting the Carmel Range we came out on to the Plain of Esdraelon, stopping at Afule & Beisan. This plain is very richindeed, the soil for the most part being chocolate in colour. At present it is looking at its best, everything being so green & fresh looking. As we were going along we saw natives ploughing in the rain though the soil was really not fit for ploughing on account of ofbeing so wet.

The country about Afule is about the richest I have so far seen. After leaving Beisan we crossed the Jordan River, near where it comes out of

Lake Tiberias , & our next stop was Samak which is on the shores of the lake, owing to the clouds & mist being so low it was impossible to see things very far away, & certainly not as well as well as in sunlight.

After leaving Samak we started to climb. Tis really marvellous the way the line is built & is a fine piece of Engineering. There are about a dozen bridges to be crossed, over Gorges etc, the surroundings of them being splendid.

At one place looking up the side of the mountain you could see the line again some hundreds of feet above us.In about 5 minutes time we were up there looking down on the valley below. There are 6 tunnels on this climb & in one place one tunnel is right over the top of another one, the line almost doing a figure 8.

The climb was pretty slow on account of it raining continually & the line being so slippery.

It was wet & dark when we got to Deraa, & so could not see the place. Owing to the wet we could not take any snaps though we saw plenty of fine pictures. We arrived in Damascus at 2330, an hour late, due to the rain & went to the Orient Hotel for the night.

The morning turned out to be nice & fine & we hope it remains so. We will be here 2 days as there is no train to Beirut until Tuesday & another on Friday.

Went through the Bazaar after Breakfast & had a good look round. The Bazaar is a tremendous big place & you can obtain there almost anything you want. They charge very high prices but you can generally beat them down to about half what they ask.

It is quite fine all day luckily & we managed to get several good photos. The city is awfully dirty the mud & slush being inches deep in all the streets & the smells in parts are enough to make one sick used as we are to Eastern towns.

There is a sytem of electric trams but it is a very poor one indeed. The town is also lit up by electric light.

The Administration of Damascus is in the hands of the Hedjaz troops. They were a big surprise to me as they are very well turned out in appearance with a good uniform & they are fair in phisique also. A lot of them are wearing English uniforms but most wear their own dress.

What surprised me most about them is that a very big proportion are very fair in complexion while others are swathy & dark like the ordinary Arab or Bedouin.

The River Barada runs through the main part of the City, flowing very swiftly & disappearing underground in the Centre of the City, running beneath the city & outcrops comes up in places. There is an abundant supply of water everywhere throughout the city but it is not used nearly as advantageously as is possible.

The sanitary & drainage system is very bad indeed but there is no reason why Damascus should not be a very clean city indeed.

This hotel is a pretty rough one, which is only to be expected I suppose. The food is very poor indeed & one not being able to get a decent meal at all & we have to supply our own blankets. We have got to stay here tomorrow too, as there is no train to Beirut until Tuesday morning.

One day is all that one requires to see Damascus as there is practically nothing to be seen except the Bazaars.



Our second day in Damascus was also fine & during the afternoon we went up onto the Hills at rear of the town & overlooking it. It gave a fine view of the city which seems to be in a huge plain covered with trees.

Left next morning at 7.30 for Beirut where we arrived at 7.00 pm having traversed a distance of about 90 odd miles in the 12 hours. The first part of the journey after leaving Damas is through the Valley of the Barada, which is rather narrow & has the road, river Barada & Railway running through it.

The River flows alongside the line & runs very swiftly. The valley has been planted very thickly with cedar trees? which grow very straight & make fine logs. This is the valley in which some of the
Entry.235:
L.H. Bde caught about 3,000 Turks & Germans & mowed them down from the sides of the hills with machine guns.

About 15 miles out we reached the source of the Barada River at the foot of the Anti-Lebanon Range. Everywhere throughout this valley was a profusion of water, coming down the rocks from springs, from waterfalls & running everywhere.

We crossed the Anti-Lebanon Range which are only about 2,500' high & then ran down to the valley of the

Leontes. There was snow on the mountains as we went over - the first time I have seen it. The valley of the Leontes is a valley about 10 - 15 miles wide, lying between two parl ranges of Mts the Lebanon & Anti-Lebanon. It is very rich indeed nearly every bit of it being under cultivation, & there are plenty of villages scattered about.

Stayed at Rayak about½ an hour & shortly afterwards started on the very steep climb up the Lebanon mountains. At Rayak one could see snow laying on the mountain tops on both sides.

It was not very cold at all except when one got out in the wind. Chaps at Rayak told us that the nights were very cold.

Shortly after leaving Rayak we started to climb the Lebanon Range. The ascent was very steep indeed & we had a rack engine on even then the pace was not above a walking pace. At the top is a tunnel & when we went through it we were on the downgrade.

On top we were going through the clouds & could not see more than about 200 yds at times. This was unfortunate as from the top there is a fine view of the mountain slopes & the Sea & Beyrout at the bottom. On top of the mountain is a big hotel, the Grand, 250 rooms, which is the summer resort for the people of Beyrout & also the Tourists.

We arrived in on time, the first time that this train has been up to time table.

Went to stay at the Victoria Hotel, which is one of the best here & is on the sea front. The tariff is 60PT'sper day which is pretty stiff as compared with Egyptian Hotels, but of course conditions are much harder here.

The town is quite European being much cleaner than Damascus, & better drained on account of being built on the hill sides. There are electric trams which are run much better than in Damascus & the town is also lit by electricity.

The Harbour is very small but is a good one & boats can tie up alongside. There are still a couple of boats lying in the harbour, which were sunk by the Italians in 1912 during the Turco-Italian War.

There is no railway stn in this place, the train running down onto the Docks. There is a station out about 2 miles, which may be the main stn. Damascus has a fine big station whereas this place has not.

It rained heavily this morning until about 9 am when it cleared up & it has been fine all day. We went out to the American College to have a look around. It is a fine place, very extensively built on the sides of the hills & overlooking the sea. The main building is a 4 storied one & is very well built. From the tower one can get a fine view of Beirut & the mountains rising at the back. The price of tuition, boarding etc is£55 per annum which is

very reasonable considering what they get for it.

The course ranges from the primary stage upwards & one can take even the degrees of B.A., M.A., dentist, medicine, etc. I would have thought that it would be called a University but tis only a College. The Rooms of the boarders are very nice roomy & clean. The Professors are all American, except perhaps those for languages. The pupils are of all nationalities & tongues but the common language is English. Everyone is taught English & encouraged to speak it, for their own good.

The military have taken over a Turkish Baths & converted it into baths for the troops. We went round there & had a cold bath today as the hot water is off but tomorrow we are going round for a hot bath & cold one after. It is a good clean place & is a good idea.Tis not often they give such concessions to the Tommies.

There is no sign now of the want & poverty that was in evidence when our people took over the place.There is plenty of bread to be had & no scarcity of vegetables.

There are some decent tram rides to be had in & around Beirut notably out to the Dog River & to the Pine Forests. There are in Beyrout the best horses that I have seen over here. Some pairswe saw in carriages were worth about£100 each. Before the war there were several hundred

carriages in & around Beyrout but of course the Turkish Army took the best of them. They are bred in Tripoli & are taller than the Egyptian Arab & finerbuilt.

In the market place we were asking the price of vegetables etc in pre war days & from what we gathered living must have been very cheap. For instance cauliflowers before the war cost 1PT for 3 or 4 decent sized ones while eggs in summer were 60 for 1/- & in winter 2 dozen per 1/-. Bread also used to be about½ the price or even lessthan we paid for it in Australia.

We had to leave Beirut on Saturday morning
Entry.236:
for Haifa going by boat. Owing to the early hour at which we started we had to sleep on the wharf overnight & be on board by 0515 am.

The boat was a drifter or mine sweeper - only about 100 tons, with no accommodation for passengers. There were 30 officers & men going down to Haifa & we just had to sit anywhere we could.

I was very sick indeed, in fact I don't think I was ever so sick before. It was not due to the rough sea as there was only a swell on but I think it must have been



due the size of the boat & to the fact that she was tossed about like a cork. I was not the only one sick, by any means.

Left Beirut at 0545 & reach Haifa at 3 pm the distance by sea being about 90 miles. At Haifa we got onto the officers train leaving at 8 pm & got to Ludd at 11 pm.

We were nor allowed to travel on the officers train unless we had tickets to go as officers batmen so we accosted officers going down who did not seem to have batmen, & asked them to get us the necessary ticket. They were very good about it & we all three had no trouble in getting tickets though we did not see any more of the officers afterwards.

At Ludd there was no car waiting so we had to walk back to the Sqdn, 2 miles away & carry our blankets & kit. It was 1 am before we got home & I was quite done up.

We were 24 hours over leave but have heard nothing of it since - I don't think we will be put up for being A.W. leave.

Tis possible now to go from Damascus to Cairo in 29 hours by train which is really good I think as the distance is about 580 - 600 miles.

Damascus is out of bounds now to all tgroops owing to an outbreak of Typhus. Tis no wonder that half the city is not wiped out with it in its present unsanitary condition.
Entry.238:
after handing over the aerodrome, machines, etc complete & came down by special train to Kantara.

We expected to be sailing on Monday by the "Ceramic" but it is off now & we will probably have to wait until the end of the month for the "Port Sydney". It seems that the Ceramic has on board some hundreds of cases if influenza & has to go into quarantine at Suez to be disinfected etc & the patients taken off her. However we may go on the Ceramic if she is only a couple of weeks in quarantine.
Entry.239:
Last Thursday went up to Cairo with a combined team from Palestine Bde to play the R.A.F. Cairo. We had 6 men in the team the remainder comprising officers from the other Squadrons.

We were up against a very strong combination & were beaten 11-0. I was knocked out in the first couple of minutes of the game - the first time since I have been since playing Rugby.

Had 48 hours leave after the match & had a good time. I bought about£10 worth of stuff to send home.

No certainty yet as to when we are going home but it is the
Entry.241:
General Allenby came this morning to say good bye to the Squadron & to thank us for the good work done since he has been G.O.C.

He is a very big man, rough & ready but is a very poor hand at making a speech & he made several grammatical errors while addressing us. He gave us a lot of soft soap etc.

We are to sail now on
Entry.242:
by the "Port Sydney".

For the past 5 days the Rhamseen has been blowing & one can hardly see more than a hundred yards or so at time due to sand.
Entry.243:
We go on the boat tomorrow morning at 9 am at Kantara landing place & leave at 11 or thereabouts. It is very hard to realise that we are leaving this country to go home as life here seems to have become the natural way of things, though none of us will be sorry to leave.

We have to pull down our own camp which has taken all day nearly. The only things left are a few tents which will be pulled down early in the morning.

The Khamseen has been blowing extra hard today accompanied by rain & at time one could not see more than 50 yds or so owing to sand which gets in ones eyes, ears, nose etc.

Some Tommy A.S.C. drivers from over the road have been getting a lot of backsheesh during the past couple of days in way of primus stoves, clothing, etc as also have Indians from nearby camps.

The battleship "New Zealand" went through the Canal this morning en route to India & Australia.

She is about the biggest vessel to date to go through the Suez Canal, the Ceramic being next.

About 20 NCO's & men left today for "A" details Moascar on leave to England. They get a months furlough on full pay & 6/- per day sustenance allowance & reembark for Australia on completion of leave.

We were only notified of it a couple of days ago & as I have slipped twice already & we are going home in a day or so, I would not take it on.

Up till a month ago I was extremely anxcious to go to Blighty but now would not take it on. Only 10% were to be allowed to go preference being given to men whose homes are in England or who have near relatives there.

There are a fair number of "Pommies" in the Sqdn and as I only wanted to go for pleasure probably would not have got a look in against them.

Have had several good swims in the Canal during the past couple of weeks but the water is a little on the cold side as yet.

During the last couple of days have received
Entry.244: parcels, bundle of Bulletins & a "Referee". Am having any parcels that come for me after I sail sent on to "Micky" Tuson.
Entry.245:
Sailed this afternoon at 4.30. During the morning we embarked about 1,000 men & officers at Kantara. This consists of 25 of our Squadron 600 leave men from "A" details Mosscar & convalescents.

Neither of the Stinsons are on board. The Boat is of roughly 9,000 tons, being very roomy but very high out of the water on account of having no cargo on board.

The troop deck runs the entire length of the ship being just under the first deck.There is plenty of light & ventilation.The ships seems in excellent condition & very clean.

There is a tremendous amount of traffic in the Canal now, & yesterday at least 2 dozen boats must have gone past us in the Canal, some of them passenger boats.

When passing through the Canal there is barely room for ships to pass so one has to pull up at certain places such as the Lake at Ismailia where there is plenty of room to allow of others passing from the opposite way.

The Canal is about 200 yds wide & a boat in the Centre going at 5 or 6 knots draws the water in towards it thus decreasing the level on the Canal banks. If the ships went too fast the water which banks up behind like a tidal wave would damage the banks considerably.

It takes about 18 hrs to go from P Said to Suez.

On first day out a chap from
Entry.246:
MG Sqdn shot himself twice in the chest. He was operated on & is recovering now. Tis said that he has had bad news from home, his mother & two sisters dying from P. Influenza.

The first day out was fairly cool but it has since warmed up but is not too hot yet.

Discipline on board is very lase & we have only one parade

a day at 0930 when orders are read.

We have averaged 13 knots per day & since starting with a favourable wind for 4 or 5 days.

In the Red Sea we met about 30 boats & passed one on each of the first 3 days.

The Mungaree is not bad at all. The first couple of days out it was light but as a result of our general complaint it was improved somewhat.375 cases of Comforts were put on at Port Said, consisting mainly of tinned fruit, syrup, jam, sauce & plenty of reading matter.

There is a fair amount of amusement on board. Our Concert party & orchastra are in full swing. Sports extending over 2 days have been held & a boxing tourament is starting in a few days.

Of course the great old game of "two up" & Crown & Anchor are much in evidence & some fair sums of money have been lost at these. One chap headed the pennies 25 times in succession one night & won£46 at it. Had it been a very big school he would have



won some hundreds.

There is not much duty on board except Guards & fatigues. We don't do the guard but get fatigue every 3 days which is not bad.

There is plenty of room on board much more than we first thought. Our troop deck extends the entire length of the ship being just under the main deck, well lit & well ventilated. We sleep up on the main deck but are not allowed up on the boat deck, it being reserved for officers.
Entry.247:
Owing to a case of smallpox breaking out everyone on board had to be vacinated today. The Nurses & orderlies nursing the case have to be isolated. He will probably be put ashore at Colombo.

Yesterday evening saw the North Star very low down on the horizon. In a few days I expect it will disappear altogether & the Southern Cross becomes visible.

Sighted the Island of Socotrathis morning
Entry.248:
at 0900 but it was nearly 3 oclock before

we had passed it. It is a very barren looking place with a population of 4,500 who do a small trade in aloes, cochineal, etc.

An educational scheme is starting today with such subjects as lower maths, English, Bookkeeping & perhaps a limited number of others. I am down for bookkeeping, to pass the time away & agriculture too if there are enough to form a class.

Quite a number of chaps have jobs on board - in cook-houses etc, to keep them occupied & fill in time. It does get monotomous on board & I get tired of reading & cannot settle my mind on it for any length of time.

Passed the Laccadive Islands quite clossely on Sunday morning & got into Colombo at tea time on following day.

We have been taking in water & coal all last night & today & won't be leaving until early tomorrow.

The ship is under close quarantine & no one except the "heads" Captain, C.O. & Doctor have been allowed ashore.

The day coming into Colombo & the day in there were exceedingly hot & we had a couple of very heavy rain storms at night.

It was very hot indeed down below & sooner than sleep down below I walked about on deck half the night, until it cleared up & then slept on deck. The heat during these two days took a lot out of most of us.

We took about 1,600 tons of coal & 2 or 3 hundred tons of water. When we went into Colombo we were drawing 15' only at the bows & 17' coming out.

Left at 10.30 on
Entry.249:
& as soon as we got out to sea & got a bit of a breeze it became much cooler. We were jolly glad to get out of Colombo & started on our journey again.

It is expected that it will take us just about 12 days to Fremantle as the coal we took on is not very good.

Arrived Fremantle
Entry.250:
morning at 4 am. We did not go inside the port but lay out in the Gage Roads, as no troopships are allowed alongside the pier. The port authorities were greatly scared over the case of smallpox we had had& had the ship listed as quarantined days before we reached port & when we arrived the Port doctor examined every man on the ship.

We landed 80 West Australians who went into quarantine. Stayed in port all day leaving at 5.30 pm. We took some water, apples & fresh vegetables.

One of my mates has an uncle onshore & received a case of apples from him. Needless to say we appreciated these very much, the first we had tasted since leaving Australia in '16.

From the way we were received at Fremantle it seems as if the returning troops are welcome in one way they are a unwelcome in other. Because we

had had a case of smallpox nearly 3 weeks ago, we were strictly quarantined & no one came near us or even sent us a message of welcome back home.

We rounded the Leevin today but did not find it very rough except for a heavy swell & kept close in to land all day. Owing to the ship being so light we were bouncing all over the place & half the time the propellors were out of the water. Owing to this we had to slaken speed somewhat.

Arrived in Adelaide about 4 pm the
Entry.251:
Were medically inspected again but the South Australians did not go ashore until 1 pm next day. We did not go into Outer Harbour but anchored outside.

We took about 600 tons of coal & left at midnight on
Entry.252:
Took on some papers which were very welcome also some fruit.

Our next destination id Hobart.

We were innoculated today against Pneumonic Flu & were glad to get a chance to be done before going off.

We had a comparitively smooth trip down to Hobart, except for the South West Coast, where it was a bit rough. We did not see Hobart but pulled into the quarantine stn in Burns Bay.

Tis a very nice place indeed & everyone was admiring the locality & saying how nice it would be to spend a holiday round there.

Stayed in overnight & pulled ot at 11 am. We had itfairly choppy in Bass Strait & quite a lot were seasick. Arrived at Portsea quarantine stn about 2 am on
Entry.253:
& left after dinner. We put ashore over 300 in all.

It was very rough coming out of the Rip but during the night it died down.

Expect to be in Sydney heads tomorrow morning about 7 am. Were innoculated todays & received certificates for it.

Arrived in Sydney on morning of
Entry.254:
at 10 am & anchored off Watsons Bay. It was a squally morning & raining most of the time.

We were a clean ship & expected not to go into quarantine camp. Landed during the afternoon & went up to a big canvas camp on top of North Head. We were in Mountain Battery tents - 6 in each only & we have straw mattresses to lie on. From our elevated position we can get an excellent view of Manly & the Harbour.

There is nothing to do except go fishing, tackle being issued for this. There is only one parade a day - 0930, to have temperatures taken.

The grub is fair but we will be glad to get out of here.

Expect to get out on Monday next.
Entry.255:
Left quarantine at 9 am arrived Anzac Buffet at 10.15 being met by motors at the wharf & taken in them to the Buffet. Met Mr Stinson, Mrs Stinson, Dr Nash, Uncle Arthur & Auntie.

Had to report at the Barracks at 12 oclock for medical examination & discharge. In just about an hour I had been through the lot & received my discharge & a fairly good civilian suit (Don't think).

Also received a leave pass up to
Entry.256: I get full pay & 3/- per day sustenance allowance during the period & I have to be out of uniform for the expiration of my leave.
Entry.257: Today sees the termination of my period of service in the A.I.F. as my discharge takes effect from today.
